commit_message:
Simplifies logic in _modify_rules

In '_modify_rules' method of iptables_manager.py, rules_index(first rule
position) can be determined in the later part of the method. Currently
rules_index value is determined early in the function and recalculated
again depending on the changes to filter.

This patch simplifies the logic by determining the 'rules_index' only
after the rules filter has the final data.

Closes-Bug: #1488747
Change-Id: I07aebbe552399e26e3dfd081827e3cf88d7f031c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/87/217087/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: rules_index = self._find_rules_index(new_filter) # backup one index so we write the array correctly if not old: rules_index -= 1

commit_message:
Remove cache of registered ports in the OVS agent

The OVS agent doesn't need to keep track of which port has
processed anymore since it consumes the events provided by
ovsdb monitor.
scan_ports and scan_ancillary_ports are called only if a resync
is needed, modify those methods to return all ports currently on
the machine as added ports.
Unit tests are modified accordingly.

Partially-Implements: blueprint restructure-l2-agent
Change-Id: Icfd7a2b7bfe30ce0d28808fefd6e3a360ebbe062

commit_message:
Refactor tunnel_sync to handle race conditions

We have a concern that we may have race conditions with existing
tunnel_sync logic with delete endpoint.

This patch-set introduces the update endpoint methods for updating
the values in VXLAN/GRE endpoint tables.

As part of code refactoring this patch-set improves the logging in
tunnel_sync for better debuging and troubleshooting.

The detailed problem statement is available in the bug description.
Closes-Bug: #1426427

Change-Id: Ic119d14e4d6a2d6d04c4288b9b0242475adf55d6

commit_message:
bind port maybe endless in the concurrent thread

the variable level may be greater than MAX_BINDING_LEVELS in
 concurrent thread,then the loop will be endless
 when the port can not be binded.

Change-Id: I0c183fc6a53e327af4a6e7a2202a2904eefce1c4

commit_message:
DO NOT MERGE - test change

This is to test that neutron changes will run VPN funcitonal tests,
initially experimental, and then later as part of check and gate.

This patch has a change in Neutron that will cause VPN functional
test for strongswan (at least) to fail. Rebased to latest Neutron.

This version does NOT have the hack, and tests should pass.

Part of the neutron-lib work.

Change-Id: Ibc4d22799287c756341c2ee332b47047d2985d83
Depends-On: Ieea93753e352ccb09f65aac12c8c81c1d96593ac

commit_message:
DO NOT MERGE - test change

This is to test that neutron changes will run VPN funcitonal tests,
in the check queue.

This patch has a change in Neutron that will cause VPN functional
test for strongswan (at least) to fail. It is testing against
stable/kilo to verify that the job works there.

commit_message:
Clean up and modernize sample files

Make the sample local.conf file conform to modern standards
and inline the webserver.sh file into local.sh.

Change-Id: I48af6ca7150282e8408e3719263da40bacb07deb

commit_message:
[WIP] Linux Bridge: Create a configurable network manager class

Create a superclass that LinuxBridgeManager inherits from, and create a
configuration option for the Linux Bridge Agent to allow other types of
VIF plugging strategies (like macvtap) to co-exist within the Linux
Bridge agent.

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-August/071416.html

Change-Id: Ic15c4839c54fa1645953bcccdd14279838e5c816
Related-Bug: #1468803

commit_message:
Exception will not be raised when Port Security is not enabled

if port_data.get(psec.PORTSECURITY) is None, the variable
 port_security is True, so AddressPairAndPortSecurityRequired
exception will not be raised for ever.

Change-Id: I7e9a8022adcdfdc30c3fc528ed84b6570c8df291

commit_message:
WIP Remove explicit network_id from IPAllocation

I've wondered why this is here.  The network_id is redundant with the
subnet_id because the subnet_id is a UUID and associates with the
network.

A quick look through the code where IPAllocation is queried, there are
a handful of places where the network_id is used in the filter but
subnet_id is always supplied too.  I don't see any queries that need
to filter on it.

Change-Id: I90abb88306ce43dfb7fcb7decb0c40b7c8f55e46
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/79/222379/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Avoid the select and delete sql pattern
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-16 23:42:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/afb1d97d6df26b1001df8a0ab2caee2c4ba09428', 'message': "Avoid the select and delete sql pattern

The following pattern:

 selected = query.filter(...).one()
 context.session.delete(selected)

is commonly used in Neutron but racy because selected can be deleted
between the select and the delete, we should prefer the pattern:

 count = query.filter(...).delete(synchronize_session=False)
 if not count:
     raise NotFound

We can set synchronize_session=False as the selected row is no
more used in session context.

TODO:
* handle remaining cases
* query.delete() doesn't offer in-python relationship cascading, so i
  need to check that

Closes-Bug: #1496586
Change-Id: Ic5136e2a9d6a6fc5a12a81ca4c2a5f9f1450901d
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-09-18 23:25:34.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/plugins/brocade/db/models.py', 'neutron/db/agents_db.py', 'neutron/db/securitygroups_db.py', 'doc/source/devref/effective_neutron.rst', 'neutron/db/qos/api.py', 'neutron/db/address_scope_db.py', 'neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py', 'neutron/db/metering/metering_db.py', 'neutron/db/flavors_db.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/d653b53a265c41fe95d8e5de0108fac627f022b6', 'message': 'Avoid the select and delete sql pattern

The following pattern:

 selected = session.query(model).filter(<on primary key>).one()
 context.session.delete(selected)

is commonly used in Neutron but racy because selected can be deleted
between the select and the delete.

We should prefer the non-racy pattern:

 # we set synchronize_session=False because the selected row is no more
 # used in session context
 count = (session.query(model).filter(<on primary key>).
          delete(synchronize_session=False))
 if not count:
     raise NotFound

except when sqlalchemy "after_delete" events are used to trace deletes
in model table. Indeed the 2 patterns raise different sqlalchemy events:

* Session.delete(1st pattern) raises "after_delete" events
* Query.delete(2nd pattern) raises "after_bulk_delete" events

And at the moment, neutron uses sqlalchemy "after_delete" events to track
resource quotas[1].

This change replaces when possible the 1st pattern by the 2nd pattern or
explicits why we should use 1st pattern.

[1] neutron.quota.resource

Closes-Bug: #1496586
Change-Id: Ic5136e2a9d6a6fc5a12a81ca4c2a5f9f1450901d
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid the select and delete sql pattern

The following pattern:

 selected = session.query(model).filter(<on primary key>).one()
 context.session.delete(selected)

is commonly used in Neutron but racy because selected can be deleted
between the select and the delete.

We should prefer the non-racy pattern:

 # we set synchronize_session=False because the selected row is no more
 # used in session context
 count = (session.query(model).filter(<on primary key>).
          delete(synchronize_session=False))
 if not count:
     raise NotFound

except when sqlalchemy "after_delete" events are used to trace deletes
in model table. Indeed the 2 patterns raise different sqlalchemy events:

* Session.delete(1st pattern) raises "after_delete" events
* Query.delete(2nd pattern) raises "after_bulk_delete" events

And at the moment, neutron uses sqlalchemy "after_delete" events to track
resource quotas[1].

This change replaces when possible the 1st pattern by the 2nd pattern or
explicits why we should use 1st pattern.

[1] neutron.quota.resource

Closes-Bug: #1496586
Change-Id: Ic5136e2a9d6a6fc5a12a81ca4c2a5f9f1450901d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/51/224351/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: count = (self._model_query(context, Flavor). filter_by(id=flavor_id). delete(synchronize_session=False)) if not count: raise FlavorNotFound(flavor_id=flavor_id) count = (context.session.query(FlavorServiceProfileBinding). filter_by(service_profile_id=service_profile_id, flavor_id=flavor_id). delete()) if not count: count = (self._model_query(context, ServiceProfile). filter_by(id=sp_id). delete(synchronize_session=False)) if not count: raise ServiceProfileNotFound(sp_id=sp_id)
deleted_lines: fl_db = self._get_flavor(context, flavor_id) context.session.delete(fl_db) binding = (context.session.query(FlavorServiceProfileBinding). filter_by(service_profile_id=service_profile_id, flavor_id=flavor_id).first()) if not binding: context.session.delete(binding) sp_db = self._get_service_profile(context, sp_id) context.session.delete(sp_db)

commit_message:
Make it possible for subclasses of Idl to be used

The OVS library now allows registering a notification hook by
subclassing the Idl class and defining a notify() method. To
be able to use this in both Neutron and networking-ovn, it must
be possible for the Connection object to use a subclassed Idl.

This patch allows either an Idl object to be passed to the
Connection, or for the library user to subclass Connection and
override the create_idl method.

The plan is for Neutron to be able to use this to avoid having to
spawn ovsdb-client monitor for syncing. networking-ovn will use
this to notify neutron of port status changes.

Closes-Bug: #1449263
Change-Id: I8d2884fe32f9ccdcd7539366e0baf055a232f2cd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/62/175062/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._idl = None self.thread = None @property def idl(self): if self._idl is None: self._idl = idl.Idl(self.connection, helper) return self._idl def start(self): with self.lock: if self.thread is not None: return
deleted_lines: self.idl = None def start(self): with self.lock: if self.idl is not None: return self.idl = idl.Idl(self.connection, helper)

commit_message:
Avoid duplicate calls to get_snat_port_for_internal_port

L3 agents internal_network_added function and
_dvr_internal_network_removed function makes a call
to get_snat_port-for_internal_port in the case of
DVR routers.

But there are duplicate calls to the same function
when snat is configured for the router interface.

This patch avoids the duplicate calls.

Closes-Bug: #1499045

Change-Id: If6e119e10fd6af5824500e298f788fe90f2e6aed
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/23/225523/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def internal_network_added(self, port, sn_port=None): if not sn_port: sn_port = self.get_snat_port_for_internal_port(port) super(DvrEdgeRouter, self).internal_network_added(port, sn_port=sn_port) def _dvr_internal_network_removed(self, port, sn_port=None): if not sn_port: sn_port = self.get_snat_port_for_internal_port(port, self.snat_ports) super(DvrEdgeRouter, self)._dvr_internal_network_removed( port, sn_port=sn_port)
deleted_lines: def internal_network_added(self, port): super(DvrEdgeRouter, self).internal_network_added(port) sn_port = self.get_snat_port_for_internal_port(port) def _dvr_internal_network_removed(self, port): super(DvrEdgeRouter, self)._dvr_internal_network_removed(port) sn_port = self.get_snat_port_for_internal_port(port, self.snat_ports)

commit_message:
[WIP] Logging API for security group and firewall rule

We would like to implement a logging API for security group and firewall rule
in order to make the trouble shooting process easier for operators
(or Cloud admins, developers etc).

This is implementation for the RFE that is tracked by [1]
and based on specification by [2]

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1468366
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/203509/

Change-Id: I44837e31a713b6f2d20aa07bc38ef67265543d1a
Co-Authored-By: Yushiro FURUKAWA <y.furukawa_2@jp.fujitsu.com>

commit_message:
GreenThread should be created when network admin_state is up

the GreenThread that configure dhcp should be created when
 admin_state is up, that is to say network.admin_state_up
 is True in function sync_state. no need to create
greenthread when admin_state is down.

Change-Id: Idf36d15e84aac631fa14909d78f2abd9b8958ee8
Closes-bug: #1497570.

commit_message:
Avoid adding flood flow when l2pop is enabled
When ovs agent start, it should not add tunnel flood flow when l2pop is enabled, because later when port is up, plugin will instructs ovs agent to install the corresponding fdb entry
Fixes Bug1312257

Change-Id: I7a44be0d12b18fc3378a4a26d8f605257d04954b

commit_message:
Use constants directly from neutron.common.constants in l3_db

Use constants directly from neutron.common.constants in l3_db
instead of defining a local constant pointing to the one in
neutron.common.constants.

Recently there was a patch that fixed constants in l3_dvr_db,
but did not touch the l3_db and this patch does the job.

commit_message:
leave skipped updated devices in 'current'

In function 'treat_devices_added_or_updated', if updated device
just removed from br-int before processing it, the device added
into 'skipped_devices', and the device removed from the set of
'current', the device's sg rules never removed from iptables.

This patch leave skipped updated devices in set of 'current',
let ovs_agent removing all sg rules about these devices.

Closes-Bug: #1489690
Change-Id: I1c211545fe6c1d5c4f13f3550b7a07f461c2b1ad

commit_message:
Allocate segment id fail with concurrency requests

Start multi neutron-server and create vxlan network with 1000
concurrency requests, but 200 return with success.

Change-Id: I4c2ea926b699af6ea4a8104fef09c2b002486dec
Closes-Bug: #1418283

commit_message:
Avoid stacktrace when dhcp port is deleted

When a dhcp port is deleted using the neutron API, dhcp agent
dumps lots of stacktrace messages (which makes debugging gate
failures a bit difficult) and re-creates the dhcp port.
This patch modifies the stacktrace to a simple warning and retains
the current behavior of re-creating [1] the dhcp-port in such situations.

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/neutron/commit/?id=9d80002

Closes-Bug: #1477190
Change-Id: I7e8ef4edd320a0f8cd6fa51ff50140435e8f1f12

commit_message:
To support ICMP codes in range [0,255]

firewall rules doesn't support to set port/port range in
 range [0,255] when selecting ICMP protocol. ICMP codes
should support to be set in range [0,255]

Closes-Bug: #1492547

Change-Id: Id2325bc7658125926053fb6aca8def4a9233f8de

"cannot find device qr" while trying to update
an arp entry for the DVR routers.

This might happen if the device was concurrently
deleted.

commit_message:
Fix cannot find device "qr" while updating arp

Logtrace for l3 agent shows errors related to
"cannot find device qr" while trying to update
an arp entry for the DVR routers.

This might happen if the device was concurrently
deleted or when the device was not created.
So it makes sense to check for the device before
trying to update an arp entry in the namespace.

If the device does not exist log a warning
message instead of throwing an exception.

This patch fixes the problem seen in the log
trace.

Related-Bug: #1419175
Change-Id: I128b9d2172690ac6854e05582fa3f05fb0ca876b

commit_message:
Security Group API: Ensure attributes are validated as UUIDs

In the API, security_group_id and remote_group_id are documented
as requiring UUIDs.

http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/api-site/tree/api-ref/src/wadls/netconn-api/src/security-groups.wadl#n347

http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/api-site/tree/api-ref/src/wadls/netconn-api/src/security-groups.wadl#n382

APIImpact

Closes-Bug: #1470076

Change-Id: I95c570d4d8b1b0b30f2ded64f11716ca9d5f8a3b

commit_message:
Make subnet_id for lbaas v2 member create optional

Presently subnet id is required for creating lbaas v2 member.
This patch makes subnet id optional for creating the member

DocImpact
APIImpact

Change-Id: I2b0619eee8dfad05c5824cf8c1f4d3f8ffd77c26
Closes-bug: #1426251

commit_message:
add script for exposing RPC APIs via HTTP

Change-Id: I7911dc4ab374cad1f8d59c62da13a5fb9d20877e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/19/235219/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """Simple script to expose RPC methods via HTTP for profiling. This script exposes several RPC methods via an HTTP API so they become very easy to invoke for profiling and debugging. Usage: python rpc_http.py --config-file /etc/neutron/neutron.conf curl http://localhost:18888/l3/get_routers/<router-id1>,<router-id2> """ from bottle import route, run from neutron.agent.common import config from neutron.agent.l3 import agent as l3_agent from neutron.agent import rpc from neutron.api.rpc.handlers import dvr_rpc from neutron.api.rpc.handlers import securitygroups_rpc from neutron.common import config as common_config from neutron.common import rpc as n_rpc from neutron import context from oslo_config import cfg import json import sys HOST = 'openstack-dev.kevindomain.local' class RPCClients(object): _instance = None def __init__(self): self.l2 = rpc.PluginApi('q-plugin') self.l3 = l3_agent.L3PluginApi('q-l3-plugin', HOST) self.dvr = dvr_rpc.DVRServerRpcApi('q-plugin') self.sg = securitygroups_rpc.SecurityGroupServerRpcApi('q-plugin') @classmethod def inst(cls): if not RPCClients._instance: RPCClients._instance = RPCClients() return RPCClients._instance @route('/l2/get_devices_details_list/<devices>') def l2_get_devices_details_list(devices): devices = devices.split(',') return json.dumps( RPCClients.inst().l2.get_devices_details_list( context.get_admin_context(), devices, 'agent_id')) @route('/sg/security_group_info_for_devices/<devices>') def sg_security_group_info_for_devices(devices): devices = devices.split(',') return json.dumps( RPCClients.inst().sg.security_group_info_for_devices( context.get_admin_context(), devices)) @route('/l3/get_routers/<routers>') def l3_get_routers(routers): routers = routers.split(',') return json.dumps( RPCClients.inst().l3.get_routers( context.get_admin_context(), routers)) @route('/dvr/get_dvr_mac_address_list') def dvr_get_dvr_mac_address_list(): return json.dumps( RPCClients.inst().dvr.get_dvr_mac_address_list( context.get_admin_context())) def init_config(): common_config.init(sys.argv[1:]) config.setup_logging() n_rpc.init(cfg.CONF) if __name__ == '__main__': init_config() run(host='0.0.0.0', port=18888)

commit_message:
Document leastrouter scheduling

Adds description of leastrouter option

Describes the router assignment behaviour of the LeastRoutersScheduler
option.
Closes-Bug: #1325458

Change-Id: I68b577586270572da54a75be0de248401fded556

commit_message:
[WIP] Linux Bridge Agent Restructuring

Basically I want the Linux Bridge agent to become like the
OVSNeutronAgent, which inherits from the RPC mixins, rather than having
a two separate classes with some interesting interactions between.

Merge LinuxBridgeRpcCallbacks and LinuxBridgeNeutronAgentRPC into a
class - LinuxBridgeNeutronAgent.

Related-Bug: #1468803
Co-Authored-By: Andreas Scheuring <andreas.scheuring@de.ibm.com>

Change-Id: I3473d256009e89defc7a1b6bdb33448fdec451ac

commit_message:
Update LBaaS L7 extension spec to reflect reality

Now that we are actually implementing Neutron LBaaS L7 functionality,
we have discovered a few discrepancies between what this spec
describes, and what we are actually having to code. This update should
bring the spec in line with what we are actually coding.

Change-Id: Iec33c480bedfb3f1504751a35bc405c5100432ef

commit_message:
Register net-update options to show help info

Register net-update options to show help info. For bool type
attributes, two options are introduced like --enable and --disable
to avoid manually passing bool parameters, similar to subnet-update
commmand.

Change-Id: I3fe1e4ca90d31b43c9ed2cf47e520b862d618a43
Closes-Bug: #1406386

added_lines: def test_update_network_with_conflicting_bool_options(self): """Update net: --enable and --disable.""" resource = 'network' cmd = network.UpdateNetwork(test_cli20.MyApp(sys.stdout), None) try: self._test_update_resource(resource, cmd, 'myid', ['myid', '--enable', '--disable'], {}) except exceptions.CommandError: return self.fail('No exception for --enable --disable option') def test_update_network_with_bool_options(self): """Update net: --enable or --disable.""" resource = 'network' cmd = network.UpdateNetwork(test_cli20.MyApp(sys.stdout), None) self._test_update_resource(resource, cmd, 'myid', ['myid', '--enable'], {'admin_state_up': True}) self._test_update_resource(resource, cmd, 'myid', ['myid', '--disable'], {'admin_state_up': False})

subject: Hyper-V Code Decomposed
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-11 10:09:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/e42111042e6e8202171cef9efcdfc5cd0a1fde08', 'message': 'Get method to retrieve firewall handle.

The implementation of this blueprint will enable
L2 neutron agent to concurrently do port binding.
The concurrency is achieved by carrying out port
binding in multiprocess (process for short interval)
environment where each process will need firewall
handle to apply security group (i.e. SG) rules.
This method will allow short living process to get
firewall handle.

Partially implements: blueprint scale-hyperv-neutron-agent

Change-Id: Iaad9d1560863ccf7092f4d01ac8ffc5c08574a0c
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-09-14 06:07:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/410e81ad2c68189681bb8dea8af17d829fdbe352', 'message': "Retrieve firewall handle & Popen for windows

The implementation of this blueprint will enable
L2 neutron agent to concurrently do port binding.
The concurrency is achieved by carrying out port
binding in multiprocess (process for short interval)
environment where each process will need firewall
handle to apply security group (i.e. SG) rules.
This method will allow short living process to get
firewall handle.

Also, modified method 'subprocess_popen' to make it
work on windows platform.

Partially implements: blueprint scale-hyperv-neutron-agent

The implementation of this blueprint will enable
L2 neutron agent to concurrently do port binding.
The concurrency is achieved by carrying out port
binding in multiprocess (process for short interval)
environment where each process will need firewall
handle to apply security group (i.e. SG) rules.
This method will allow short living process to get
firewall handle.

main() method in hyperv_neutron_agent.py is
changed to pass cmd line argument, the arguments
will decide which methods to be invoker in class
"HyperVNeutronAgent" in parent and child process
context.

New config parameters are introduced to decide
on how many parallel child process can created
for port processing, and on failure how many
retires are allowed before giving up.

l2_agent.py file is re-factored to support
concurrent port binding.

Partially implements: blueprint scale-hyperv-neutron-agent

Change-Id: Iaad9d1560863ccf7092f4d01ac8ffc5c08574a0c

commit_message:
Output resource uuid when a resource is created

the log output mechanism has been already implemented in oslo.log[1],
this patch just adds "resource" information to log.

Followings are sample executed "neutron net-create".
 *configure file
   logging_context_format_string =
       %(asctime)s.%(msecs)03d %(color)s%(levelname)s %(name)s
       [%(request_id)s %(user_name)s %(project_id)s%(color)s]
       %(resource)s%(color)s%(message)s

 *souruce file
  rscdict = {'type': 'network',
             'id': '8e6a748c-aa8a-440b-904a-a6e2f6dc00eb'}
  LOG.debug("network create success", resource=rscdict)

 *log file
  DEUG [req-1667753a-e5f5-4417-bd8d-16f12bcc2e34 admin
       0862ba8c3497455a8fdf40c49f0f2644] [network-8e6a748c-
       aa8a-440b-904a-a6e2f6dc00eb] network create success

 [1]
 https://review.openstack.org/#/c/144813/

Change-Id: I789cefa4d1b742562d3d54e25f0932032e74dd68
Closes-Bug: #1468723

commit_message:
IP Address Auto-Completion with FWaaS Command

Neutron FWaaS currently allows users to specify IP addresses
in incomplete formats in commands such as
"neutron firewall-rule-create", but does not translate it into
the complete format -- for example, if a "--source-ip-address"
is set to "1/32", it will be registered in the database as "1/32",
instead of "1.0.0.0/32". The patch ensures that the IP address is
registered in the complete format.

because it is complemented by FW rule creation from the horizon or
other neutron commands,
fwaas complements the IP address as well as their
such as the options to specify the IP address
is set the "1/32", and it is registered as "1.0.0.0/32" on database
the case of the above example.

Change-Id: I494f84d6ba318264d747f983904130841f1e2c19

commit_message:
DO NOT MERGE: Trying out Guru Meditation Report

I posited that it would be nice to have a way to get a thread dump (a-la
JVM) on a running process then realized we have Guru Meditation Reports
in oslo_reports.

To fire handler kill -s SIGUSR1 [pid].

Change-Id: If288ef2392388dc7079c6aa739446928187f97db

commit_message:
Change log level warn to debug to avoid frequent warn

"No DHCP agents available, skipping rescheduling" is reported
 so frequently in function remove_networks_from_down_agents when
 there is none active agent.the log is not very useful but so
 many log will make it difficult to read log information.

Closes-bug: #1492773

Change-Id: I7a1524834c8f970381e40681f532bf8d9916693e

commit_message:
Only use lsb_release for distro tags

The existing GetOSVersion has a lot of unused code which is wrong in
several ways

 - the only path tested in upstream CI is with lsb_release, because
   it's pre-installed on all nodes

 - the /etc/redhat-release checking probably still works, but is
   unnecessary

 - If using lsb_release, os_UPDATE has never actually been set.

 - the /etc/SuSE-release branch checking is broken if the lsb package
   is actually installed.  lsb checking does not set os_UPDATE but yet
   the SuSE DISTRO setting relies on this to set a patch level (and so
   does some of the rpm tags).  SuSE 11 is up to update 3, but the rpm
   matching is stuck hard-coded to update 2.  I'm guessing
   installation is actually broken there.

 - the debian checking branch is broken.  The VERSION tags have been
   removed and were not supposed to be relied on anyway (see notes in
   [1])

This simplifies things:

 - remove OSX checking (moved here after discussions in
   I31d0fdd30928ecc8d959a95838b1d3affd28ac6f)

 - only use the output of lsb_release.

 - A small best-effort check to pre-install lsb packages if not
   detected (that avoids chicken-egg-problem of package-install
   wrappers relying on os_* flags).

 - The unset os_UPDATE is removed.  It's only previous use was for
   setting separate suse versions in the DISTRO element for matching
   during package installs (since removed) -- the same could be
   achieved by parsing os_RELEASE if required.

[1] http://sources.debian.net/src/base-files/7.5/debian/changelog/

Change-Id: I46a2c36d95327087085df07cb797eb91249a893c

commit_message:
Optimize "open" method with context manager

Replace the classic open() with opening context manager to open
files which is in the create_iscsi_target methods of volume targets.

Change-Id: I12e19801a21b1279308983fd0257dae9c9653641

commit_message:
Remove version from setup.cfg

Per [1] we now want to use the git repository for knowing the version instead
of just trying to modify the setup.cfg file.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-November/080692.html

Change-Id: I790506ea15e67f0cdeaed62b5b87a7d51c589e7b

commit_message:
Delete python bytecode before every test run

Bring over the cleaning line from run_tests.sh for the pyc files to
all the tox runs.

This should eliminate the need to clean -x -i to kill pyc files in
your local directory to get tests to pass.

Change-Id: Ib095a107537446d6e43a222cf68f7b84b9368f60
Closes-Bug: #1368661

subject: Fix PostgreSQL root functions
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-09 20:11:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/1f5b58b58bc4be7824aa52ee0ba8cd254deadfb0', 'message': 'Fix PostgreSQL root functions

The default PostgreSQL administration account is 'postgres'.

This account always exists and cannot be removed.
Its attributes and access can however be altered.

Clients can connect from the localhost or remotely via TCP/IP:

Local clients (e.g. psql) can connect from a preset *system* account
called 'postgres'.
This system account has no password and is *locked* by default,
so that it can be used by *local* users only.
It should *never* be enabled (or it's password set)!!!
That would just open up a new attack vector on the system account.

Remote clients should use a build-in *database* account of the same
name. It's password can be changed using the "ALTER USER" statement.

Access to this account is disabled by Trove exposed only once the
superuser access is requested.

In the current implementation Trove uses the 'postgres' account and
return a new superuser called 'root' when the root access is requested.
The user 'root' has however no special meaning in PostgreSQL and the
existing applications may rely on the default superuser name 'postgres'.

This patch includes the following fixes:

 - Make Trove create and use its own administrative account (os_admin).
 - Disable (disable logins) the built-in 'postgres' account by default.
 - Enable and return the 'postgres' user when the root access is
   requested.
 - Fix failure on repeated 'root-enable' calls. The new implementation
   just regenerates the user's password.
 - Prevent users from hijacking the 'os_admin' account by allowing only
   local access.
 - Use the existing framework to generate secure passwords.

Notes:

 The current implementation is broken for variaous reasons:

 - It uses UUIDs in place of 'secure' password.
 - It creates a 'root' user, but no database for it.
   The clients won't be able to authenticate without explicitly
   providing an existing database name.
 - The created 'root' user has no 'SUPERUSER' attribute and
   hence is not a real superuser (cannot perform certain tasks)...
 - The implementation suffers a defect that allows a non-root user
   gain root access to an instance without marking is as 'root-enabled'
   A similar defect exists in other datastores (MySQL) too:

     1. Create an instance.
     2. Enable root.
     3. Use your root access to change the password of the built-in
        'postgres' account (Trove will still work because it uses the
        'peer' authentication method - the UNIX account).
     4. Login as 'postgres' using the changed password and drop the
        created 'root' account.
     5. Backup & restore the instance.
     6. Trove reports the root has never been enabled (it checks for existence of
        superuser accounts other than the built-in 'postgres').
     7. You enjoy the root access of the 'postgres' user
        (the password is not reset on restore).

Change-Id: Ie56ac0850bf4de742ce7841195ce29ca3b30c9ef
Closes-Bug: 1514569

commit_message:
Fix PostgreSQL root functions

The default PostgreSQL administration account is 'postgres'.

This account always exists and cannot be removed.
Its attributes and access can however be altered.

Clients can connect from the localhost or remotely via TCP/IP:

Local clients (e.g. psql) can connect from a preset *system* account
called 'postgres'.
This system account has no password and is *locked* by default,
so that it can be used by *local* users only.
It should *never* be enabled (or it's password set)!!!
That would just open up a new attack vector on the system account.

Remote clients should use a build-in *database* account of the same
name. It's password can be changed using the "ALTER USER" statement.

Access to this account is disabled by Trove exposed only once the
superuser access is requested.

In the current implementation Trove uses the 'postgres' account and
return a new superuser called 'root' when the root access is requested.
The user 'root' has however no special meaning in PostgreSQL and the
existing applications may rely on the default superuser name 'postgres'.

This patch includes the following fixes:

 - Make Trove create and use its own administrative account (os_admin).
 - Disable (disable logins) the built-in 'postgres' account by default.
 - Enable and return the 'postgres' user when the root access is
   requested.
 - Fix failure on repeated 'root-enable' calls. The new implementation
   just regenerates the user's password.
 - Prevent users from hijacking the 'os_admin' account by allowing only
   local access.
 - Use the existing framework to generate secure passwords.
 - Stop using the system 'postgres' user to execute command-line client
   calls. Communicate with database via a native Python interface
   (like other datastores) instead.
 - Remove unnecessary complex result-set caching on the guest.
 - Simplify the status-checking code using the native exceptions.
   Avoid performing complex checks with uncertain benefits
   (i.e. attempt to guess the state of the process).

Notes:

 The current implementation is broken for variaous reasons:

 - It uses UUIDs in place of 'secure' password.
 - It creates a 'root' user, but no database for it.
   The clients won't be able to authenticate without explicitly
   providing an existing database name.
 - The created 'root' user has no 'SUPERUSER' attribute and
   hence is not a real superuser (cannot perform certain tasks)...
 - The implementation suffers a defect that allows a non-root user
   gain root access to an instance without marking is as 'root-enabled'
   A similar defect exists in other datastores (MySQL) too:

     1. Create an instance.
     2. Enable root.
     3. Use your root access to change the password of the built-in
        'postgres' account (Trove will still work because it uses the
        'peer' authentication method - the UNIX account).
     4. Login as 'postgres' using the changed password and drop the
        created 'root' account.
     5. Backup & restore the instance.
     6. Trove reports the root has never been enabled (it checks for
        existence of superuser accounts other than the built-in
        'postgres').
     7. You enjoy the root access of the 'postgres' user
        (the password is not reset on restore).

Depends-On: I9d6b3df5bebc3c499cea8306f5a1a6bab18adef6
Change-Id: Ie56ac0850bf4de742ce7841195ce29ca3b30c9ef
Closes-Bug: 1514569
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/92/243292/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import pgutil from trove.common import utils PG_BUILTIN_ADMIN = 'postgres' pgutil.PG_ADMIN = self.PG_BUILTIN_ADMIN pgutil.PG_ADMIN = self.ADMIN_USER else: self._secure(context) def _secure(self, context): # Create a new administrative user for Trove and also # disable the built-in superuser. self.create_database(context, [{'_name': self.ADMIN_USER}]) self._create_admin_user(context) pgutil.PG_ADMIN = self.ADMIN_USER postgres = {'_name': self.PG_BUILTIN_ADMIN, '_password': utils.generate_random_password()} self.alter_user(context, postgres, 'NOSUPERUSER', 'NOLOGIN')

commit_message:
carbonara: move aggregated() to AggregatedTimeSerie

The plan is to deprecate TimeSerieArchive, so this patch moves the
aggregated method that we will still need to AggregatedTimeSerie. The
method now deals directly with AggregatedTimeSerie rather than
TimeSerieArchive, but works in the same way.

Change-Id: I62bde8b5972387ba33f9ef58ef664aebbe059056
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi refs/changes/87/248087/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def fetch(self, from_timestamp=None, to_timestamp=None): """Fetch aggregated time value. Returns a sorted list of tuples (timestamp, granularity, value). """ points = self[from_timestamp:to_timestamp] try: # Do not include stop timestamp del points[to_timestamp] except KeyError: pass return [(timestamp, self.sampling, value) for timestamp, value in six.iteritems(points)] @staticmethod def aggregated(timeseries, from_timestamp=None, to_timestamp=None, aggregation='mean', needed_percent_of_overlap=100.0): index = ['timestamp', 'granularity'] columns = ['timestamp', 'granularity', 'value'] dataframes = [] if not timeseries: return [] for timeserie in timeseries: timeserie_raw = timeserie.fetch(from_timestamp, to_timestamp) if timeserie_raw: dataframe = pandas.DataFrame(timeserie_raw, columns=columns) dataframe = dataframe.set_index(index) dataframes.append(dataframe) if not dataframes: return [] number_of_distinct_datasource = len(timeseries) / len( set(ts.sampling for ts in timeseries) ) grouped = pandas.concat(dataframes).groupby(level=index) left_boundary_ts = None right_boundary_ts = None maybe_next_timestamp_is_left_boundary = False holes = 0 for (timestamp, __), group in grouped: if group.count()['value'] != number_of_distinct_datasource: maybe_next_timestamp_is_left_boundary = True holes += 1 elif maybe_next_timestamp_is_left_boundary: left_boundary_ts = timestamp maybe_next_timestamp_is_left_boundary = False else: right_boundary_ts = timestamp if to_timestamp is not None and from_timestamp is not None: maximum = len(grouped) percent_of_overlap = (float(maximum - holes) * 100.0 / float(maximum)) if percent_of_overlap < needed_percent_of_overlap: raise UnAggregableTimeseries( 'Less than %f%% of datapoints overlap in this ' 'timespan (%.2f%%)' % (needed_percent_of_overlap, percent_of_overlap)) elif (needed_percent_of_overlap > 0 and (right_boundary_ts == left_boundary_ts or (right_boundary_ts is None and maybe_next_timestamp_is_left_boundary))): LOG.debug("We didn't find points that overlap in those " "timeseries. " "right_boundary_ts=%(right_boundary_ts)s, " "left_boundary_ts=%(left_boundary_ts)s, " "groups=%(groups)s" % { 'right_boundary_ts': right_boundary_ts, 'left_boundary_ts': left_boundary_ts, 'groups': list(grouped) }) raise UnAggregableTimeseries('No overlap') # NOTE(sileht): this call the aggregation method on already # aggregated values, for some kind of aggregation this can # result can looks wierd, but this is the best we can do # because we don't have anymore the raw datapoints in those case. # FIXME(sileht): so should we bailout is case of stddev, percentile # and median? agg_timeserie = getattr(grouped, aggregation)() agg_timeserie = agg_timeserie.dropna().reset_index() if from_timestamp is None and left_boundary_ts: agg_timeserie = agg_timeserie[ agg_timeserie['timestamp'] >= left_boundary_ts] if to_timestamp is None and right_boundary_ts: agg_timeserie = agg_timeserie[ agg_timeserie['timestamp'] <= right_boundary_ts] points = (agg_timeserie.sort_values(by=['granularity', 'timestamp'], ascending=[0, 1]).itertuples()) return [(timestamp, granularity, value) for __, timestamp, granularity, value in points]

" "right_boundary_ts=%(right_boundary_ts)s, " "left_boundary_ts=%(left_boundary_ts)s, " "groups=%(groups)s" % { 'right_boundary_ts': right_boundary_ts, 'left_boundary_ts': left_boundary_ts, 'groups': list(grouped) }) raise UnAggregableTimeseries('No overlap') # NOTE(sileht): this call the aggregation method on already # aggregated values, for some kind of aggregation this can # result can looks wierd, but this is the best we can do # because we don't have anymore the raw datapoints in those case. # FIXME(sileht): so should we bailout is case of stddev, percentile # and median? agg_timeserie = getattr(grouped, aggregation)() agg_timeserie = agg_timeserie.dropna().reset_index() if from_timestamp is None and left_boundary_ts: agg_timeserie = agg_timeserie[ agg_timeserie['timestamp'] >= left_boundary_ts] if to_timestamp is None and right_boundary_ts: agg_timeserie = agg_timeserie[ agg_timeserie['timestamp'] <= right_boundary_ts] points = (agg_timeserie.sort_values(by=['granularity', 'timestamp'], ascending=[0, 1]).itertuples()) return [(timestamp, granularity, value) for __, timestamp, granularity, value in points]

storage: make exception inherits from StorageError

This makes it easier to catch any storage error.

Change-Id: I4a092d95c9338b11cb5cf10e8ee9f8c81fce9226

commit_message:
Fix documentation on get_alarm

get_alarm returns alarm_definition, not alarm_definition_id
get_alarm doesn't return description

commit_message:
Remove version from setup.cfg

Per email from the release team [1], we are moving to using only
tags and removing verisons from setup.cfg.

Depends-On: I19e888fc403aa2d95b769ed1730721eba29e68ea
[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-November/080692.html

Change-Id: I02f0f5a18d7587c429d150ad7da2decbb609b045
Signed-off-by: Kyle Mestery <mestery@mestery.com>

commit_message:
Accept v2 params to v3 service create

v2 clouds exist. So do v3 clouds. If the cloud is v3 but the user
tries v2 names, just do the right thing.

Change-Id: Iaceff4b2e3e6faf3923ae08064c6bddb264df514

commit_message:
Anchor support to Octavia

Use Anchor for certificate signing to make the octavia communication
more secure. Anchor Ref url: https://github.com/openstack/anchor

Co-Authored-By: bharath <bharath.stacker@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: German Eichberger <german.eichberger@hp.com>

Change-Id: Id77b2b1540377db661f15d4eeafc4922f446d987
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/77/242277/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2015 Hewlett Packard Enterprise Development Company LP # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import binascii import os from OpenSSL import crypto from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_log import log as logging import requests import six from octavia.certificates.common import local as local_common from octavia.certificates.generator import local from octavia.common import exceptions from octavia.i18n import _LE, _LI LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) CONF = cfg.CONF CONF.import_group('anchor', 'octavia.common.config') class AnchorCertGenerator(local.LocalCertGenerator): """Cert Generator Interface that signs certs with Anchor.""" @classmethod def sign_cert(cls, csr): """Signs a certificate using our private CA based on the specified CSR :param csr: A Certificate Signing Request :return: Signed certificate :raises Exception: if certificate signing fails """ LOG.info(_LI( "Signing a certificate request using Anchor." )) try: # csr = """ # -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE REQUEST----- # MIICZzCCAU8CAQAwIjEgMB4GA1UEAwwXYW5jaG9yLXRlc3QuZXhhbXBsZS5jb20w # ggEiMA0GCSqGSIb3DQEBAQUAA4IBDwAwggEKAoIBAQC/jsNc81kFCXvCh+wO0aai # 9ucRO8qlCXeMcLjN8UpLpun7x4PU9FEkiV6YHhP71SJCrKm+vq9LunI/6W0PffjE # v6lo8eyr5h3LJR83yaLU08VDs+avrz2jO4kwTsO+KQGEhoRablSF6BXSBXhzOzUn # sfZlschvvaXtZQCCwUfWIzLlvasbDQAVi8AFkMaodBBsj/Rq8kq8B+5fY9Q/OqCv # 2x4ksoSddpNc3LBFuzpgUC3lhBrmsKZrqda8qxD4naqBs6Y5OOCdds0Xd0wlbzJ7 # 8gtqArlWG9pOtjfVTH7lwsWPY/3mbIT3VDmcSw1onI100prlPsrmIALR7R4YBzrZ # AgMBAAGgADANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQsFAAOCAQEAsssdRXln/MZ3LHPQNz1So8X8COHy # 9pn5kjMrv25RTsi8MQ5afipq9JT29yvUN2XMEnTQZ2Kfc+M6CaPysTKi/MJKCx++ # L4OUB5wO5sS+F8yNk8dVq5HfLayBlzAK9jxjngV6NseaqEWNBMUGeKWZsZnFxja1 # 1N0RFxsJ3f+TwkHuOOSjOnqhzTSUYZU/tgTlnlTRgESKvVpNykE7QNDOk9FE2WU2 # cZv42NKvJSchUqkbdgSrnJDY5V7voy1/CophXRI+8ZZGb25BkxRnNOo8NRYnh2Y9 # WvSjh/Gw9T+70dGTqq7LpJECg+tfKRxx8Enay1mbuGoFBYXKCxgmJG5L9g== # -----END CERTIFICATE REQUEST----- # """ r = requests.post(CONF.anchor.url, data={ 'user': CONF.anchor.username, 'secret': CONF.anchor.password, 'encoding': 'pem', 'csr': csr}) if r.status_code != 200: raise "Invalid Status Code : " + str(r.status_code) return r.content #crypto.dump_certificate(crypto.FILETYPE_PEM, new_cert) except Exception as e: LOG.error(_LE("Unable to sign certificate.")) raise exceptions.CertificateGenerationException(msg=e)

Remove version from setup.cfg

Per [1] we now want to use the git repository for knowing the version instead
of just trying to modify the setup.cfg file.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-November/080692.html

commit_message:
Put py34 first in the env order of tox

To solve the problem of "db type could not be determined" on py34 we
have to run first the py34 env to, then, run py27. This patch puts py34
first on the tox.ini list of envs to avoid this problem to happen.

Change-Id: I7e279cbb3a6c4710b8361c8cc2df368bd28c3203
Closes-Bug: #1489059
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/93/252393/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: envlist = py34,py27,pep8

commit_message:
Remove OSX "support"

This is already about 4 versions out of date.  Let's clear this up,
but leave a sane error message behind.

Change-Id: I31d0fdd30928ecc8d959a95838b1d3affd28ac6f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/18/252718/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # negative check for OSX; people try it and we want to give a sane # failure. die $LINENO "OSX is not a supported platform"
deleted_lines: function _get_version_osx { os_VENDOR=$(sw_vers -productName) os_RELEASE=$(sw_vers -productVersion) os_PACKAGE="" if [[ "$os_RELEASE" =~ "10.7" ]]; then os_CODENAME="lion" elif [[ "$os_RELEASE" =~ "10.6" ]]; then os_CODENAME="snow leopard" elif [[ "$os_RELEASE" =~ "10.5" ]]; then os_CODENAME="leopard" elif [[ "$os_RELEASE" =~ "10.4" ]]; then os_CODENAME="tiger" elif [[ "$os_RELEASE" =~ "10.3" ]]; then os_CODENAME="panther" else os_CODENAME="" fi export os_VENDOR os_RELEASE os_PACKAGE os_CODENAME } # check for OSX first up _get_version_osx return

commit_message:
Fix db error when running python34 Unit tests

If tests for py27 is executed before py34 tests, then
there is a chance that py34 related tests may fail.The following
patch fixes it.

Ref: https://review.openstack.org/#/q/status:merged++topic:bug/1489059,n,z

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I78452096ef8df7de7ae977d96d020f74255cd336
Closes-bug: #1489059

commit_message:
Merge attribute definion

Devices and VNFs, device_templates and VNFDs are having the same
attr definition. This patch removes the duplications.

Change-Id: I5036dc3fcf56d17ea598dc2d38f08e3c0d447676
Closes-bug: 1520131

subject: keystone_user fails if auth_url ends with '/' in Openrc
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-03 19:50:15.000000000', 'files': ['lib/puppet/provider/keystone_user/openstack.rb'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone/commit/70c0ab9e635a9c1f394bcf5f5c53e1986afc8d90', 'message': 'keystone_user fails if auth_url ends with '/' in Openrc

Having /root/openrc with
OS_AUTH_URL='http://127.0.0.1:5000/v2.0/' (notice the "/" at the end)
makes keystone_user password verification fails.

Change-Id: If321bae1aa235ef6e6c7faead32c8056c81252dc
Closes-Bug: #1522550
'}]
commit_message:
keystone_user fails if auth_url ends with '/' in Openrc

Having /root/openrc with
OS_AUTH_URL='http://127.0.0.1:5000/v2.0/' (notice the "/" at the end)
makes keystone_user password verification fails.

Change-Id: If321bae1aa235ef6e6c7faead32c8056c81252dc

commit_message:
Functional: only copy logs on exception

This patch adds a copy_logs as the handler with unittest's addOnException,
by doing this, we can get logs for all failed cases instead of copy them
before teardown.

If without any failed case, don't copy logs for saving time.

Partially implements: blueprint swarm-functional-testing
Change-Id: I47725d0d16735f650adf325adcf4194eb70c384d

commit_message:
Fix ZFSSA drivers' local cache bugs

- Use image_utils to retrieve an image's virtual_size on the fly.
- Fix race conditions happened when multiple bootable volumes are
created and deleted simultaneously.
- Handle a situation in iSCSI driver when custom schema are deleted.

Change-Id: I588fb6c668f2a891ab24d89fea26536dd0cd5742
Closes-Bug: #1498965
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/54/229554/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cinder.image import image_utils @utils.synchronized('zfssaiscsi', external=True) A file lock is placed on this method to prevent: (a) a race condition when a cache volume has been verified, but then gets deleted before it is cloned. (b) failure of subsequent clone_image requests if the first request is still pending. cachevol_size = 0 with image_utils.TemporaryImages.fetch(image_service, context, image_meta['id']) as tmp_image: info = image_utils.qemu_img_info(tmp_image) cachevol_size = int(math.ceil(float(info.virtual_size) / units.Gi)) if (not cache_vol.get('updated_at', None) or not cache_vol.get('image_id', None)): exc_msg = (_('Cache volume %s does not have required ' 'properties'), cachevol_name) LOG.error(exc_msg) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data=exc_msg) try: self.zfssa.delete_lun(lcfg.zfssa_pool, lcfg.zfssa_cache_project, cache['share']) except exception.VolumeBackendAPIException: pass
deleted_lines: # virtual_size is the image's actual size when stored in a volume # virtual_size is expected to be updated manually through glance try: virtual_size = int(image_meta['properties'].get('virtual_size')) except Exception: LOG.error(_LE('virtual_size property is not set for the image.')) return None, False cachevol_size = int(math.ceil(float(virtual_size) / units.Gi)) @utils.synchronized('zfssaiscsi', external=True) There needs to be a file lock here, otherwise subsequent clone_image requests will fail if the first request is still pending. self.zfssa.delete_lun(lcfg.zfssa_pool, lcfg.zfssa_cache_project, cache['share'])

commit_message:
remove version from setup.cfg

Following the instructions that are provided in the mailing list [0].
We need to remove the version line from setup.cfg, as from now
on releases will be tagged using the release tools rather
than version being set in setup.cfg

[0] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-November/080692.html

Change-Id: I3be169b5cbc8040585486137dafaf6eafd16bc58
Depends-On: I658a63bdd47633ff35066e61e874c67a3ac02d92

commit_message:
Start removal of namespace package

This moves the namespace package to akanda_neutro, and adds a shim
which allows neutron to still load the plugins with the old path.
Shim can be removed once devstack plugin is updated.

Change-Id: Ie06f2087dceeff91bebd32bd33901950a282f792
Partially-Implements: blueprint convert-to-astara

AIX can't handle having its VOpt mapping removed while it's live.  We

HTTP error 500 for method POST on path
/rest/api/uom/VirtualIOServer/656B0AC3-35D4-4E06-892E-FD3EACA09737?gro

Change-Id: I9205f471628788fc7e5230bee0944b2c2434c1d2
"}]
commit_message:
Detach vopt from mappings if VM is live

AIX can't handle having its VOpt mapping removed while it's live.  We
can see VIOS errors like:

HTTP error 500 for method POST on path
/rest/api/uom/VirtualIOServer/656B0AC3-35D4-4E06-892E-FD3EACA09737?gro
up=ViosSCSIMapping: Internal Server Error -- [PVME0105FF05-0187] Command
drmgr -c slot -s 'U8247.22L.212E63A-V6-C3' -r returned 1. Additional
messages:
0931-029 The specified slot contains a device or devices that are
currently configured. Unconfigure the following device or devices with
the rmdev command and try again.

In this change set, we check whether the VM is live, and if so, rather
than deleting the mapping entirely, we remove the Storage and
TargetDevice fields, thus detaching the storage from the mapping.

Change-Id: I9205f471628788fc7e5230bee0944b2c2434c1d2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm refs/changes/91/253091/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Some VMs can't handle having their vopt mappings removed while running, so if the VM is active, we instead preserve the mapping, but detach the vopt from it. :param lpar_uuid: The pypowervm UUID of the LPAR whose vopt is to be removed. def detach_vopt_from_mapping(vios_w): """Detach the virtual optical device from the mapping.""" # TODO(IBM): Request this function in pypowervm. # Remove the maps and re-add them with no storage rms = tsk_map.remove_maps(vios_w, lpar_uuid, match_func=match_func) adds = [] for rmap in rms: new_map = pvm_vios.VSCSIMapping._bld(rmap.adapter) if rmap.client_lpar_href is not None: new_map._client_lpar_href(rmap.client_lpar_href) if rmap.client_adapter is not None: new_map._client_adapter(copy.deepcopy(rmap.client_adapter)) if rmap.server_adapter is not None: new_map._server_adapter(copy.deepcopy(rmap.server_adapter)) adds.append(new_map) vios_w.scsi_mappings.extend(adds) return adds # If the partition is live... state = vm.get_vm_qp(self.adapter, lpar_uuid, qprop='PartitionState') if state in ("running"): # Add a function to detach the vopt from the map stg_ftsk.wrapper_tasks[self.vios_uuid].add_functor_subtask( detach_vopt_from_mapping) else: # Add a function to remove the map stg_ftsk.wrapper_tasks[self.vios_uuid].add_functor_subtask( rm_vopt_mapping)
deleted_lines: :param lpar_uuid: The pypowervm UUID of the LPAR to remove. # Add a function to remove the map stg_ftsk.wrapper_tasks[self.vios_uuid].add_functor_subtask( rm_vopt_mapping)

Rename from akanda_neutron -> astara_neutron

Renames the module and updates imports, references and deprecates
config in favor of newly named equivs.

commit_message:
Document the custom remote-code-block directive

Change-Id: I8fdea3aa262e2b1e86849ba61195af6babefe2bf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/85/252885/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _remote-block: Literal block using a remote file ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ +-----------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ | **Directive** | ``remote-code-block`` | +-----------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ | **Arguments** | ``python`` (default), ``ruby``, ``c``, ``console``, | | | ``ini``, and others | +-----------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ | **Options** | ``linenos``, ``emphasize-lines`` | +-----------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ | **Description** | * Specifies the highlighting language directly. | | | * Preserves line breaks and whitespaces. | +-----------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ This directive behaves exactly like the ``code-block`` directive, but gets the content from a remote URL (``http`` or ``https``). ``remote-code-block`` is a custom directive. **Input** .. code:: .. remote-code-block:: ini https://raw.githubusercontent.com/openstack/nova/master/etc/nova/api-paste.ini **Output** .. code-block:: ini ############ # Metadata # ############ [composite:metadata] use = egg:Paste#urlmap /: meta [pipeline:meta] pipeline = cors ec2faultwrap logrequest metaapp

commit_message:
Backup snapshots

Today we can backup volumes, but not snapshots. This spec proposes
to provide a way to backup snapshots.

blueprint backup-snapshots

Change-Id: Ie8a16f49257ae172b6ce68158c8eda742d3a0076
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/05/232305/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Backup Snapshots ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/backup-snapshots Currently we can backup a volume, but not a snapshot, though backing up an in-use volume may be achieved by backing up a temporary snapshot. This blueprint proposes to provide a way to backup snapshots. Problem description =================== Today we can backup a volume, but we cannot directly backup a snapshot. The process of backing up an in-use volume may involve creating a temporary snapshot and backing up the temporary snapshot. So we can leverage the existing techniques to backup a snapshot directly. Use Cases ========= There are customers who have taken many snapshots and would like a way to protect those snapshots. This proposal to backup snapshots provides another layer of data protection. Proposed change =============== For the default implementation, it can be achieved as follows: * Create a temporary volume from the snapshot * Attach the temporary volume * Do backup from the temporary volume * Detach the temporary volume * Cleanup temporary volume If the driver has implemented the attach_snapshot interface, backing up a snapshot can be done as follows: * Attach the snapshot * Do backup from the snapshot * Detach the snapshot For incremental backups, because the latest parent is calculated automatically by looking at the timestamps, the logic has to be changed to accommodate backups from snapshots. For backups from snapshots, we need to look at the timestamps of the snapshots; For backups from volumes, we still look at the timestamps of the backups as before. Alternatives ------------ Here is an alternative: * Create a volume from the snapshot. * Backup the volume. * Delete the volume. Data model impact ----------------- Add the following new column to the backups table for snapshot id. This field will be null if the backup is from a volume. snapshot_id = Column(String(36)) Note that the following column will still be required for a backup from snapshot: volume_id = Column(String(36), nullable=False) REST API impact --------------- Change the existing create backup API to take a snapshot id. Either "volume_id" or "snapshot_id" has to be provided for the create backup API, but not both. The "snapshot_id" is required for backing up a snapshot. * Create backup * V2/<tenant id>/backups * Method: POST * JSON schema definition for V2:: { "backup": { "display_name": "nightly001", # existing "display_description": "Nightly backup", # existing "volume_id": "xxxxxxxx", # existing "snapshot_id": "xxxxxxxx", # new "container": "nightlybackups", ...... } } The following driver API will be added to support backup snapshot. * def backup_snapshot(self, context, backup, backup_service) Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- End user will be able to create a backup from a snapshot. Performance Impact ------------------ No obvious performance impact. Other deployer impact --------------------- The deployer will be able to backup a snapshot. Developer impact ---------------- Driver developers can override the default backup_snapshot implementation if their driver can support attach_snapshot. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <xing-yang> Other contributors: <None> Work Items ---------- * Make changes to backup API to support backup snapshot. * Make changes to the backups db table to add a snapshot_id column. * Make changes in backup manager to support backup snapshot. * Add a default driver implementation to backup a snapshot. * Make changes to incremental backups to take into account backups created from snapshots. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests will be provided. Documentation Impact ==================== Documentation will be modified to describe this feature. References ==========

commit_message:
Use assertRaises instead of try-except in unit tests

Change-Id: I1fde8f078363e66b0992c5874ae52d35a8c9cb68
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib refs/changes/37/251437/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import functools def _raise(exc_class, **kwargs): raise exc_class(**kwargs) def _check_nexc(self, exc_class, expected_msg, **kwargs): raise_exc_class = functools.partial(_raise, exc_class) e = self.assertRaises(exc_class, raise_exc_class, **kwargs) self.assertEqual(expected_msg, str(e)) self.assertFalse(e.use_fatal_exceptions())
deleted_lines: def _check_nexc(self, exc_class, e_msg, **kwargs): try: raise exc_class(**kwargs) except exc_class as e: self.assertEqual(e.msg, e_msg) self.assertFalse(e.use_fatal_exceptions())

commit_message:
Test if OS_TEST_TIMEOUT works at the gate

It works locally, I want to see if it works at the gate.
Otherwise I'm not clear why we're seeing tests running
for thousands of seconds.

Change-Id: Ia895f4d11b06af0b83829197feaef130d1427e52
Related-Bug: #1521815

subject: Don't remove vOpt mapping on live migrate
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-03 21:47:22.000000000', 'files': ['nova_powervm/tests/virt/powervm/test_live_migration.py', 'nova_powervm/virt/powervm/media.py', 'nova_powervm/tests/virt/powervm/test_media.py', 'nova_powervm/virt/powervm/live_migration.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm/commit/336043f61097c2e4bf0c5173297d895ad7d17017', 'message': "Don't remove vOpt mapping on live migrate

Some operating systems are unable to remove a device when it is in use.
However, during a live migrate, we can't migrate the the virtual optical
device.

The current live migrate code was removing the virtual optical media,
but also was removing the mapping.  This change updates it to leave the
mapping (so that operating systems that can't remove the bus are OK),
but to detach the vopt device from it.  We still remove the virtual
optical media.

Change-Id: Id2a3216ec06e95a538fa2f9f25463c490d69f81f
Closes-Bug: 1522222
"}]
commit_message:
Don't remove vOpt mapping on live migrate

Some operating systems are unable to remove a device when it is in use.
However, during a live migrate, we can't migrate the the virtual optical
device.

The current live migrate code was removing the virtual optical media,
but also was removing the mapping.  This change updates it to leave the
mapping (so that operating systems that can't remove the bus are OK),
but to detach the vopt device from it.  We still remove the virtual
optical media.

Change-Id: Id2a3216ec06e95a538fa2f9f25463c490d69f81f
Closes-Bug: 1522222

commit_message:
Don't remove vOpt mapping on live migrate

Some operating systems are unable to remove a device when it is in use.
However, during a live migrate, we can't migrate the the virtual optical
device.

The current live migrate code was removing the virtual optical media,
but also was removing the mapping.  This change updates it to leave the
mapping (so that operating systems that can't remove the bus are OK),
but to detach the vopt device from it.  We still remove the virtual
optical media.

Change-Id: Id2a3216ec06e95a538fa2f9f25463c490d69f81f
Closes-Bug: 1522222

commit_message:
Adding manila shares as an option for data sources

Data sources located on a Manila share are now
an option in the create data source UI.  Also including
a unit test.

Change-Id: Ic3b3f2469eb05e53d819b7df50b5632c7bdad94c
Partial-Implements: bp manila-as-a-data-source

added_lines: CREATE_URL = reverse( 'horizon:project:data_processing.data_sources:create-data-source') @test.create_stubs({api.manila: ('share_list', ), api.sahara: ('data_source_create', ), api.sahara.base: ('is_service_enabled', )}) def test_create(self): share = self.mox.CreateMockAnything() share.id = "tuvwxy56-1234-abcd-abcd-defabcdaedcb" share.name = "Test Share" shares = [share] api.sahara.base.is_service_enabled(IsA(http.HttpRequest), IsA(str)) \ .AndReturn(True) api.sahara.data_source_create(IsA(http.HttpRequest), IsA(unicode), IsA(unicode), IsA(unicode), IsA(str), "", "").AndReturn(True) api.manila.share_list(IsA(http.HttpRequest)).AndReturn(shares) self.mox.ReplayAll() form_data = { "data_source_type": "manila", "data_source_manila_share": share.id, "data_source_url": "/testfile.bin", "data_source_name": "testmanila", "data_source_description": "Test manila description", } res = self.client.post(CREATE_URL, form_data) self.assertNoFormErrors(res)

commit_message:
Adding support for Manila-based shares in Sahara

The Sahara data processing service now supports manila
shares as a location for job binaries.  Also adding a unit
test for creation of manila-based job binaries.

Change-Id: I06a21cd159de76aa7b70f6f26af3dad2d14598b6
Implements: bp add-manila-binary-store

subject: Servicegroup foundational refactoring for Control Plane
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-11 00:53:55.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs/commit/a82086b4066b42c91573415cfd1c7ea48a368793', 'message': "Servicegroup foundational refactoring for Control Plane

At present, there are various interfaces through which services data can
be manipulated - admin interface(nova-manage), extensions
(contrib/services.py), servicegroup API layer. Having different
interfaces to manipulate the source of truth can lead to severe
data inconsistency for something as useful as stored in nova.services.
The proposal is to follow a common path, while interacting with services
data, for all the three interfaces mentioned above. This common path will
go through the servicegroup layer, who's primary purpose is to manage
and check for service liveliness. Doing so will help to overcome the
tight coupling between nova and services database and also have a
consistent view of services data, service liveliness, etc.

Change-Id: I3cae9495373c4334fedb18b64d907f3a6ac5ab92
Previously-approved: liberty
Implements: blueprint servicegroup-api-control-plane

commit_message:
Servicegroup foundational refactoring for Control Plane

At present, there are various interfaces through which services data
can  be manipulated - admin interface(nova-manage), extensions
(contrib/services.py), etc. Every interface relies on the servicegroup
layer API is_up() to get details about service live-ness. The proposal
is keep service data in nova database nova.services table and fetch
the live-ness information from the configured servicegroup(SG) driver.
Liveness will be a combination of service live-ness and RPC live-ness,
where the later will be computed based on information in nova.services.

Previously-approved: liberty
Implements: blueprint servicegroup-api-control-plane

Change-Id: I3cae9495373c4334fedb18b64d907f3a6ac5ab92
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/23/222423/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================================================= Servicegroup foundational refactoring for Control Plane ======================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/servicegroup-api-control-plane At present, there are various interfaces through which services data can be manipulated - admin interface(nova-manage), extensions (contrib/services.py), servicegroup API layer. Having different interfaces to manipulate the source of truth can lead to severe data inconsistency for something as useful as stored in nova.services. The proposal is to follow a common path, while interacting with services data, for all the three interfaces mentioned above. This common path will go through the servicegroup API layer, who's primary purpose is to manage and check for service liveliness. Doing so will help to overcome the tight coupling between nova and services table and also have a consistent view of services data, service liveliness, etc. Problem description =================== 1. There is a tight coupling between nova and the nova.services table. Before making a decision about liveliness of a service running on a particular host nova refers to the services table which is considered as a source of truth. 2. At present there are 3 interfaces, namely admin interface(nova-manage), extensions, servicegroup API layer, from which the service information is either accessed or modified. 3. Database servicegroup driver is the primary driver used by most of the deployments. But for deployments using Zookeeper or Memcache servicegroup driver, we will end up in severe data inconsistency given that we have 3 different interfaces to modify the critical services information which is stored in nova db. 4. There is no abstraction provided to choose a different backend to store the service data. It is tightly coupled with database as a backend and stored in nova.services table. Before Nova was introduced to the world of objects, services data was fetched by making database queries through the sqlalchemy layer. After the implementation of the objects layer also the data is fetched from database. Just the means to access data has changed not the location where the services data is placed. This has been covered in more detail in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/138607/. The scope of of this spec is limited to calls accesing and fetching service data and service liveliness information by enforcing all the interfaces go through the servicegroup api layer. Use Cases --------- 1. Deployment using Zookeeper servicegroup driver to manage service liveliness : In this case, even though Zookeeper servicegroup driver is being used to manage services and to report service liveliness but the admin interface(nova-mange) and the extension interface which act on nova.services table, which they consider as the source of truth for services information, can lead to severe data inconsistencies. 2. An operator uses admin interface, nova-manage service disable, to mark a service down. Zookeeper won't be aware of this change and still thinks service is up and running. So nova-manage only works with database as the underlying backend. The admin interface uses servicegroup layer for checking service liveliness but then does db query to get the list of services. This is inconsistent with the servicegroup driver API 'get_all' view on what is enabled/diabled. 3. An operator using Nova service delete(REST api) seems to follow the similar broken pattern mentioned above and only works with database as the underlying backend. This implementation is also inconsistent with servicegroup driver API 'get_all' view of services data. Project Priority ---------------- None Proposed change =============== 1. Proposed change is to enforce all the changes to services data go through the servicegroup APIs. 2. Fix all places in the code which access/modify the services data by querying/modifying nova.services and there are many places in nova codebase which do that. 3. If the services information is stored in database, all the interfaces will go through servicegroup API layer. New interfaces will be added to servicegroup API to handle these changes. For example update() call needs to be added so that admin interface can change the state of the service using nova-manage, which will eventually go through servicegroup API update(). 4. If the services information is stored in Zookeeper or Memcache all the interfaces which access/modify services data, service liveliness information will go through servicegroup API. The details on how the Zookeeper ephemeral znode will maintain the service representational state and how to migrate from existing database servicegroup driver to zookeeper servicegroup driver has been covered in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/138607. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- 1. Inorder to fetch services details like service information, service liveliness, the call should go through servicegroup API rather than directly fetching the information either through sqlalchemy layer and then db or using service objects. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: vilobhmm Other contributors: jaypipes, harlowja Work Items ---------- - Fix admin interface, nova-manage, to use servicegroup API rather than directly querying database. - Fix REST API extensions for os-hosts, os-hypervisors, os-services and os-availability-zones to use servicegroup API. All of these use direct calls to objects. ServiceList or host_api.service_get_all (which is hard-coded to use objects.ServiceList.get_all, which queries the database services table and does not actually hit the servicegroup API at all). Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= 1. Unit tests will be added if needed. 2. Existing unit tests will be updated to make sure the services data is accessed/updated using the servicegroup API. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== - http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-May/063602.html - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/138607

commit_message:
remove code to locate the default config file

The configuration file was previously loaded into the test.  These are defaults
options and should not need to be read from a configuration file.

Change-Id: I5e704a135e9d4a483cbc884b62cb0d4134ec389a

added_lines: .. Warning: Do not edit this file. It is automatically generated from the software project's code and your changes will be overwritten. The tool to generate this file lives in openstack-doc-tools repository. Please make any changes needed in the code, then run the autogenerate-config-doc tool from the openstack-doc-tools repository, or ask for help on the documentation mailing list, IRC channel or meeting. .. _neutron-quotas: .. list-table:: Description of quotas configuration options :header-rows: 1 :class: config-ref-table * - Configuration option = Default value - Description * - **[DEFAULT]** - * - ``max_routes`` = ``30`` - (IntOpt) Maximum number of routes per router * - **[QUOTAS]** - * - ``default_quota`` = ``-1`` - (IntOpt) Default number of resource allowed per tenant. A negative value means unlimited. * - ``quota_driver`` = ``neutron.db.quota.driver.DbQuotaDriver`` - (StrOpt) Default driver to use for quota checks * - ``quota_firewall`` = ``1`` - (IntOpt) Number of firewalls allowed per tenant. A negative value means unlimited. * - ``quota_firewall_policy`` = ``1`` - (IntOpt) Number of firewall policies allowed per tenant. A negative value means unlimited. * - ``quota_firewall_rule`` = ``100`` - (IntOpt) Number of firewall rules allowed per tenant. A negative value means unlimited. * - ``quota_floatingip`` = ``50`` - (IntOpt) Number of floating IPs allowed per tenant. A negative value means unlimited. * - ``quota_health_monitor`` = ``-1`` - (IntOpt) Number of health monitors allowed per tenant. A negative value means unlimited. * - ``quota_healthmonitor`` = ``-1`` - (IntOpt) Number of health monitors allowed per tenant. A negative value means unlimited. * - ``quota_items`` = ``network, subnet, port`` - (ListOpt) Resource name(s) that are supported in quota features. This option is now deprecated for removal. * - ``quota_listener`` = ``-1`` - (IntOpt) Number of Loadbalancer Listeners allowed per tenant. A negative value means unlimited. * - ``quota_loadbalancer`` = ``10`` - (IntOpt) Number of LoadBalancers allowed per tenant. A negative value means unlimited. * - ``quota_member`` = ``-1`` - (IntOpt) Number of pool members allowed per tenant. A negative value means unlimited. * - ``quota_network`` = ``10`` - (IntOpt) Number of networks allowed per tenant. A negative value means unlimited. * - ``quota_pool`` = ``10`` - (IntOpt) Number of pools allowed per tenant. A negative value means unlimited. * - ``quota_port`` = ``50`` - (IntOpt) Number of ports allowed per tenant. A negative value means unlimited. * - ``quota_rbac_entry`` = ``10`` - (IntOpt) Default number of RBAC entries allowed per tenant. A negative value means unlimited. * - ``quota_router`` = ``10`` - (IntOpt) Number of routers allowed per tenant. A negative value means unlimited. * - ``quota_security_group`` = ``10`` - (IntOpt) Number of security groups allowed per tenant. A negative value means unlimited. * - ``quota_security_group_rule`` = ``100`` - (IntOpt) Number of security rules allowed per tenant. A negative value means unlimited. * - ``quota_subnet`` = ``10`` - (IntOpt) Number of subnets allowed per tenant, A negative value means unlimited. * - ``quota_vip`` = ``10`` - (IntOpt) Number of vips allowed per tenant. A negative value means unlimited. * - ``track_quota_usage`` = ``True`` - (BoolOpt) Keep in track in the database of current resourcequota usage. Plugins which do not leverage the neutron database should set this flag to False

commit_message:
HOT outputs were merged

This commit does dot HOT template outputs (for Heat.HOT/1.0 format)
the same that was previously done for the inputs. Instead of generating
MuranoPL property per each output now all outputs are put into a
single 'templateOutputs' property. This allows to eliminate the constraints
on output names, not to have collisions with input names and remain
consistent with previous changes.

Change-Id: Ibbd0a2f410c55385cd3cb9e85ea135a36460afe7
Closes-Bug: #1520954

This cycle, to address these problems for our ever-growing set of
projects, the release management team is introducing a new tool for
handling release notes as files in-tree, to allow us to simply and
continuously build the release notes for stable branch point releases
and milestones on the master branch. The idea is to use small YAML
files, usually one per note or patch, to avoid merge conflicts on
backports and then to compile those files in a deterministic way
into a more readable document for readers. Files containing release
