commit_message:
Add reno for release notes management

This cycle, to address these problems for our ever-growing set of
projects, the release management team is introducing a new tool for
handling release notes as files in-tree, to allow us to simply and
continuously build the release notes for stable branch point releases
and milestones on the master branch. The idea is to use small YAML
files, usually one per note or patch, to avoid merge conflicts on
backports and then to compile those files in a deterministic way
into a more readable document for readers. Files containing release
notes can be including in patches directly, or you can create a
separate patch with release notes if you want to document a feature
than spans several patches.  The tool is called Reno, and it currently
supports ReStructuredText and Sphinx for converting note input files
to HTML for publication.  Reno is git branch-aware, so we can have
separate release notes documents for each release series published
together from the master build.

-- Excerpted from Doug Hellmann's email to the mailing list
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-November/078301.html

For more information about Reno:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/reno/

Change-Id: I4028d52f5e67d2873b3dc9df279f78a15c35d84f
(cherry picked from commit 1519d5a0862178d9b5351447214835adb8b1ac2c)

Conflicts:
	test-requirements.txt

Change-Id: I4028d52f5e67d2873b3dc9df279f78a15c35d84f

commit_message:
Update link in release notes to anonymous link

Using two underscores changes the link to anymonlous.
This fixes the warning - Duplicate explicit target name: this.

Change-Id: If9fad79110db7bd37112de244127da7d038328c6

commit_message:
Remove version from setup.cfg

Per [1] we now want to use the git repository for knowing the version
instead of just trying to modify the setup.cfg file.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-November/080692.html

Change-Id: I857b50f6b4284b44ff7a10315437b31ae2b0c8a8
Depends-On: I7860e230da5b5ee517c1568aed2127bdb9c6ee7e

commit_message:
Add testing for ObjectVersionChecker fixture

This change adds testing infra for the fixture module, and starts out by
adding tests for the ObjectVersionChecker fixture.

Change-Id: I3057cbba6eddaddea2d8287e3f1a21eaf31104fc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.versionedobjects refs/changes/92/252092/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015 IBM Corp. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import collections import copy import hashlib import mock import six from oslo_versionedobjects import base from oslo_versionedobjects import fields from oslo_versionedobjects import fixture from oslo_versionedobjects import test class MyObject(base.VersionedObject): fields = {'diglett': fields.IntegerField()} @base.remotable def remotable_method(self): pass @classmethod @base.remotable def remotable_classmethod(cls): pass def non_remotable_method(self): pass @classmethod def non_remotable_classmethod(cls): pass class MyObject2(base.VersionedObject): pass class MyExtraObject(base.VersionedObject): pass class TestObjectVersionChecker(test.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestObjectVersionChecker, self).setUp() objects = [MyObject, MyObject2, ] self.obj_classes = {obj.__name__: [obj] for obj in objects} self.ovc = fixture.ObjectVersionChecker(obj_classes=self.obj_classes) def test_get_hashes(self): fp = 'ashketchum' with mock.patch.object(self.ovc, '_get_fingerprint') as mock_gf: mock_gf.return_value = fp actual = self.ovc.get_hashes() expected = self._generate_hashes(self.obj_classes, fp) self.assertEqual(expected, actual, "ObjectVersionChecker is not " "getting the fingerprints of all registered " "objects.") def test_test_hashes_none_changed(self): fp = 'pikachu' hashes = self._generate_hashes(self.obj_classes, fp) with mock.patch.object(self.ovc, 'get_hashes') as mock_gh: mock_gh.return_value = hashes # I'm so sorry, but they have to be named this way actual_expected, actual_actual = self.ovc.test_hashes(hashes) expected_expected = expected_actual = {} self.assertEqual(expected_expected, actual_expected, "There are no " "objects changed, so the 'expected' return value " "should contain no objects.") self.assertEqual(expected_actual, actual_actual, "There are no " "objects changed, so the 'actual' return value " "should contain no objects.") def test_test_hashes_class_not_added(self): fp = 'gyrados' new_classes = copy.copy(self.obj_classes) self._add_class(new_classes, MyExtraObject) expected_hashes = self._generate_hashes(self.obj_classes, fp) actual_hashes = self._generate_hashes(new_classes, fp) with mock.patch.object(self.ovc, 'get_hashes') as mock_gh: mock_gh.return_value = actual_hashes actual_exp, actual_act = self.ovc.test_hashes(expected_hashes) expected_expected = {MyExtraObject.__name__: None} expected_actual = {MyExtraObject.__name__: fp} self.assertEqual(expected_expected, actual_exp, "Expected hashes " "should not contain the fingerprint of the class " "that has not been added to the expected hash " "dictionary.") self.assertEqual(expected_actual, actual_act, "The actual hash " "should contain the class that was added to the " "registry.") def test_test_hashes_new_fp_incorrect(self): fp1 = 'beedrill' fp2 = 'snorlax' expected_hashes = self._generate_hashes(self.obj_classes, fp1) actual_hashes = copy.copy(expected_hashes) actual_hashes[MyObject.__name__] = fp2 with mock.patch.object(self.ovc, 'get_hashes') as mock_gh: mock_gh.return_value = actual_hashes actual_exp, actual_act = self.ovc.test_hashes(expected_hashes) expected_expected = {MyObject.__name__: fp1} expected_actual = {MyObject.__name__: fp2} self.assertEqual(expected_expected, actual_exp, "Expected hashes " "should contain the updated object with the old " "hash.") self.assertEqual(expected_actual, actual_act, "Actual hashes " "should contain the updated object with the new " "hash.") def test_get_dependency_tree(self): with mock.patch.object(self.ovc, '_get_dependencies') as mock_gd: self.ovc.get_dependency_tree() expected_calls = [(({}, MyObject),), (({}, MyObject2),)] self.assertEqual(sorted(expected_calls), sorted(mock_gd.call_args_list), "get_dependency_tree() did not get the dependencies " "of the objects correctly.") def test_test_relationships_none_changed(self): dep_tree = {} # tree will be {'MyObject': {'MyObject2': '1.0'}} self._add_dependency(MyObject, MyObject2, dep_tree) with mock.patch.object(self.ovc, 'get_dependency_tree') as mock_gdt: mock_gdt.return_value = dep_tree actual_exp, actual_act = self.ovc.test_relationships(dep_tree) expected_expected = expected_actual = {} self.assertEqual(expected_expected, actual_exp, "There are no " "objects changed, so the 'expected' return value " "should contain no objects.") self.assertEqual(expected_actual, actual_act, "There are no " "objects changed, so the 'actual' return value " "should contain no objects.") def test_test_relationships_rel_added(self): exp_tree = {} actual_tree = {} self._add_dependency(MyObject, MyObject2, exp_tree) self._add_dependency(MyObject, MyObject2, actual_tree) self._add_dependency(MyObject, MyExtraObject, actual_tree) with mock.patch.object(self.ovc, 'get_dependency_tree') as mock_gdt: mock_gdt.return_value = actual_tree actual_exp, actual_act = self.ovc.test_relationships(exp_tree) expected_expected = {'MyObject': {'MyObject2': '1.0'}} expected_actual = {'MyObject': {'MyObject2': '1.0', 'MyExtraObject': '1.0'}} self.assertEqual(expected_expected, actual_exp, "The expected " "relationship tree is not being built from changes " "correctly.") self.assertEqual(expected_actual, actual_act, "The actual " "relationship tree is not being built from changes " "correctly.") def test_test_relationships_class_added(self): exp_tree = {} actual_tree = {} self._add_dependency(MyObject, MyObject2, exp_tree) self._add_dependency(MyObject, MyObject2, actual_tree) self._add_dependency(MyObject2, MyExtraObject, actual_tree) with mock.patch.object(self.ovc, 'get_dependency_tree') as mock_gdt: mock_gdt.return_value = actual_tree actual_exp, actual_act = self.ovc.test_relationships(exp_tree) expected_expected = {'MyObject2': None} expected_actual = {'MyObject2': {'MyExtraObject': '1.0'}} self.assertEqual(expected_expected, actual_exp, "The expected " "relationship tree is not being built from changes " "correctly.") self.assertEqual(expected_actual, actual_act, "The actual " "relationship tree is not being built from changes " "correctly.") def test_test_compatibility_routines(self): del self.ovc.obj_classes[MyObject2.__name__] with mock.patch.object(self.ovc, '_test_object_compatibility') as toc: self.ovc.test_compatibility_routines() toc.assert_called_once_with(MyObject) def test_test_relationships_in_order(self): with mock.patch.object(self.ovc, '_test_relationships_in_order') as mock_tr: self.ovc.test_relationships_in_order() expected_calls = [((MyObject,),), ((MyObject2,),)] self.assertEqual(sorted(expected_calls), sorted(mock_tr.call_args_list), "test_relationships_in_order() did not test the " "relationships of the individual objects correctly.") def test_test_relationships_in_order_positive(self): rels = {'bellsprout': [('1.0', '1.0'), ('1.1', '1.2'), ('1.3', '1.3')]} MyObject.obj_relationships = rels self.ovc._test_relationships_in_order(MyObject) def test_test_relationships_in_order_negative(self): rels = {'rattata': [('1.0', '1.0'), ('1.1', '1.2'), ('1.3', '1.1')]} MyObject.obj_relationships = rels self.assertRaises(AssertionError, self.ovc._test_relationships_in_order, MyObject) def test_find_remotable_method(self): method = self.ovc._find_remotable_method(MyObject, MyObject.remotable_method) self.assertEqual(MyObject.remotable_method.original_fn, method, "_find_remotable_method() did not find the remotable" " method of MyObject.") def test_find_remotable_method_classmethod(self): rcm = MyObject.remotable_classmethod method = self.ovc._find_remotable_method(MyObject, rcm) expected = rcm.__get__(None, MyObject).original_fn self.assertEqual(expected, method, "_find_remotable_method() did not " "find the remotable classmethod.") def test_find_remotable_method_non_remotable_method(self): nrm = MyObject.non_remotable_method method = self.ovc._find_remotable_method(MyObject, nrm) self.assertIsNone(method, "_find_remotable_method() found a method " "that isn't remotable.") def test_find_remotable_method_non_remotable_classmethod(self): nrcm = MyObject.non_remotable_classmethod method = self.ovc._find_remotable_method(MyObject, nrcm) self.assertIsNone(method, "_find_remotable_method() found a method " "that isn't remotable.") def test_get_fingerprint(self): MyObject.VERSION = '1.1' argspec = 'vulpix' with mock.patch('inspect.getargspec') as mock_gas: mock_gas.return_value = argspec fp = self.ovc._get_fingerprint(MyObject.__name__) exp_fields = sorted(list(MyObject.fields.items())) exp_methods = sorted([('remotable_method', argspec), ('remotable_classmethod', argspec)]) expected_relevant_data = (exp_fields, exp_methods) expected_hash = hashlib.md5(six.binary_type(repr( expected_relevant_data).encode())).hexdigest() expected_fp = '%s-%s' % (MyObject.VERSION, expected_hash) self.assertEqual(expected_fp, fp, "_get_fingerprint() did not " "generate a correct fingerprint.") def test_get_fingerprint_with_child_versions(self): child_versions = {'1.0': '1.0', '1.1': '1.1'} MyObject.VERSION = '1.1' MyObject.child_versions = child_versions argspec = 'onix' with mock.patch('inspect.getargspec') as mock_gas: mock_gas.return_value = argspec fp = self.ovc._get_fingerprint(MyObject.__name__) exp_fields = sorted(list(MyObject.fields.items())) exp_methods = sorted([('remotable_method', argspec), ('remotable_classmethod', argspec)]) exp_child_versions = collections.OrderedDict(sorted( child_versions.items())) exp_relevant_data = (exp_fields, exp_methods, exp_child_versions) expected_hash = hashlib.md5(six.binary_type(repr( exp_relevant_data).encode())).hexdigest() expected_fp = '%s-%s' % (MyObject.VERSION, expected_hash) self.assertEqual(expected_fp, fp, "_get_fingerprint() did not " "generate a correct fingerprint.") def test_get_dependencies(self): self._add_class(self.obj_classes, MyExtraObject) MyObject.fields['subob'] = fields.ObjectField('MyExtraObject') MyExtraObject.VERSION = '1.0' tree = {} self.ovc._get_dependencies(tree, MyObject) expected_tree = {'MyObject': {'MyExtraObject': '1.0'}} self.assertEqual(expected_tree, tree, "_get_dependencies() did " "not generate a correct dependency tree.") def test_test_object_compatibility(self): to_prim = mock.MagicMock(spec=callable) MyObject.VERSION = '1.1' MyObject.obj_to_primitive = to_prim self.ovc._test_object_compatibility(MyObject) expected_calls = [((), {'target_version': '1.0'}), ((), {'target_version': '1.1'})] self.assertEqual(expected_calls, to_prim.call_args_list, "_test_object_compatibility() did not test " "obj_to_primitive() on the correct target versions") def _add_class(self, obj_classes, cls): obj_classes[cls.__name__] = [cls] def _generate_hashes(self, classes, fp): # Generate hashes for classes, giving fp as the fingerprint # for all classes return {cls: fp for cls in classes.keys()} def _add_dependency(self, parent_cls, child_cls, tree): # Add a dependency to the tree with the parent class holding # version 1.0 of the given child class deps = tree.get(parent_cls.__name__, {}) deps[child_cls.__name__] = '1.0' tree[parent_cls.__name__] = deps

commit_message:
Use choices for neutron_sync_mode option

The neutron_sync_mode option allows the following options:
off, repair or log. This leverages the oslo_config validation.

Change-Id: Ic68232ecab4dd9afba35f3ad6f3c38c4eacb2eb0

commit_message:
Neutron: Use generated configuration files if available

Generate the neutron core sample config files by using the oslo
generator. The files are generated with a .sample extension and
replace the static example configuration files.

Once the generation code is delivered, the static config files
will be removed.

Change-Id: Ic37a16b6cf8eb92030649f1fc8b198738a8cc104
Related-blueprint: autogen-neutron-conf-file
Partial-bug: #1199963
Depends-On: I1c6dc4e7d479f1b7c755597caded24a0f018c712
Co-Authored-By: Louis Taylor <louis@kragniz.eu>

subject: Handle unbound allowed_address_pair FIP with DVR
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-16 02:40:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/12b4a69bd82235e9e3832009a0714e10b4aec970', 'message': 'Update device info for FIP paired port w/unbound

When an unbound port gets associated with an FIP entry in DVR
environment, this port needs to be identified as a DVR service port
in order for DVR schedulers to know it is serviceable by DVR routers.
If a FIP port is paired with a VM hosted port, which falls into the
unbound port case, its host and device info needs to get updated.
Once the paired port's host and device info get updated, it is tagged
as a DVR service port. There are use cases the tenant will use the
unbound port in DVR environment such as "VRRP".

Without this fix, there is a chance that FIP agent gateway port will
get deleted on the DVR host as the system would think there is no
DVR service port presented, because this port is not tagged as DVR
serviceable. This would happen when a port is disassociated from
floating IP entry. At that point, system performs the check if FIP
agent gateway port is DVR serviceable on the host based on the device
owner type. If it is not, the port get deleted. However, in reality,
this port should not get deleted.

Change-Id: I7f17630550e203535421c55721c9d9486d6435aa
Closes-Bug: #1475096
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-07-16 02:56:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/802e7c1e5af116456ce7ebea7c4c8e824a0b1a68', 'message': 'Update device info for FIP paired port w/unbound

When an unbound port gets associated with an FIP entry in DVR
environment, this port needs to be identified as a DVR service port
in order for DVR schedulers to know it is serviceable by DVR routers.
If a FIP port is paired with a VM hosted port, which falls into the
unbound port case, its host and device info needs to get updated.
Once the paired port's host and device info get updated, it is tagged
as a DVR service port. There are use cases the tenant will use the
unbound port in DVR environment such as "VRRP".

Without this fix, there is a chance that FIP agent gateway port will
get deleted on the DVR host as the system would think there is no
DVR service port presented, because this port is not tagged as DVR
serviceable. This would happen when a port is disassociated from
floating IP entry. At that point, system performs the check if FIP
agent gateway port is DVR serviceable on the host based on the device
owner type. If it is not, the port get deleted. However, in reality,
this port should not get deleted.

Change-Id: I7f17630550e203535421c55721c9d9486d6435aa
Closes-Bug: #1475096
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-07-16 21:38:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/93b23570ec7447bea749402b4419b221a91a15a2', 'message': 'Update device info for FIP paired port w/unbound

When an unbound port gets associated with an FIP entry in DVR
environment, this port needs to be identified as a DVR service port
in order for DVR schedulers to know it is serviceable by DVR routers.
If a FIP port is paired with a VM hosted port, which falls into the
unbound port case, its host and device info needs to get updated.
Once the paired port's host and device info get updated, it is tagged
as a DVR service port. There are use cases the tenant will use the
unbound port in DVR environment such as "VRRP".

Without this fix, there is a chance that FIP agent gateway port will
get deleted on the DVR host as the system would think there is no
DVR service port presented, because this port is not tagged as DVR
serviceable. This would happen when a port is disassociated from
floating IP entry. At that point, system performs the check if FIP
agent gateway port is DVR serviceable on the host based on the device
owner type. If it is not, the port get deleted. However, in reality,
this port should not get deleted.

Change-Id: I7f17630550e203535421c55721c9d9486d6435aa
Closes-Bug: #1475096
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2015-07-16 21:40:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/53161b46aaa1baa3f67f076842c0067315413314', 'message': 'Update device info for FIP paired port w/unbound

When an unbound port gets associated with an FIP entry in DVR
environment, this port needs to be identified as a DVR service port
in order for DVR schedulers to know it is serviceable by DVR routers.
If a FIP port is paired with a VM hosted port, which falls into the
unbound port case, its host and device info needs to get updated.
Once the paired port's host and device info get updated, it is tagged
as a DVR service port. There are use cases the tenant will use the
unbound port in DVR environment such as "VRRP".

Without this fix, there is a chance that FIP agent gateway port will
get deleted on the DVR host as the system would think there is no
DVR service port presented, because this port is not tagged as DVR
serviceable. This would happen when a port is disassociated from
floating IP entry. At that point, system performs the check if FIP
agent gateway port is DVR serviceable on the host based on the device
owner type. If it is not, the port get deleted. However, in reality,
this port should not get deleted.

Change-Id: I7f17630550e203535421c55721c9d9486d6435aa
Closes-Bug: #1475096
'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2015-07-17 18:34:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/0d423ea19aa9d906a4fc39ef9535cb8a8dc98ef7', 'message': "Handle unbound allowed_address_pair FIP with DVR

When an unbound allowed_address_pair port gets associated with an FIP
entry in DVR, this port needs to be identified as a DVR service port.
If an allowed-address-pair port associated with a Floating IP is
configured to a VM port, the allowed-address-pair port will need to
adopt the VM port's host binding to be DVR serviceable.

When a port get disassociated from floating IP entry, system would
perform the check whether this FIP agent gateway port is DVR
serviceable on the host based on the device owner type. If it is not,
this port can get removed. However, if this port is in used meaning it
is bound with a host that has same device owner as the VM host port, it
should remain in the system.

VRRP is one of use cases for this scenario.

Change-Id: I7f17630550e203535421c55721c9d9486d6435aa
Closes-Bug: #1475096

commit_message:
Handle unbound allowed_address_pair FIP with DVR

If an allowed-address-pair port associated with a Floating IP is configured to
a VM port, the allowed-address-pair port will need to adopt the VM port's host
binding to be DVR serviceable.

DocImpact
Change-Id: I7f17630550e203535421c55721c9d9486d6435aa
Closes-Bug: #1475096
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/60/202360/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def update_paired_port_for_unbound_port_vm(self, context, port_dict): """Update paired port information for unbound port case One use case is creating VM by assigning unbound port. Migrating host and device information from unbound port to its paired port if it is found on the floating IP table. After VM created, host name and device information will be assigned to the unbound port. And, its paired port should get updated accordingly as well. """ portPairs = port_dict['allowed_address_pairs'] if portPairs: address_pair_ip = portPairs[0]['ip_address'] LOG.debug("allowed address pair IP=%s ", address_pair_ip) filters = {'fixed_ips': {'ip_address': [address_pair_ip]}} ports = self._core_plugin.get_ports(context, filters=filters) for port in ports: #check if paired port in fip table. #if so, go ahead updating host and device info fip = self._get_floatingip_on_port(context, port_id=port['id']) if fip: port_ip = port['fixed_ips'][0]['ip_address'] if (address_pair_ip == port_ip): try: hostId = port_dict['binding:host_id'] devOwner = port_dict['device_owner'] devId = port_dict['device_id'] self._core_plugin.update_port( context, port['id'], {'port': {portbindings.HOST_ID: hostId, 'device_owner': devOwner, 'device_id': devId}}) except AttributeError: LOG.debug("No host_id attribute in port dict.")

Update puppet-neutron Hiera config

To reflect new changes [1], we need to update the Hiera config, so we
don't have a warning when running Puppet.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/puppet-neutron/commit/46d6242644d580d3bfa7c21e20a2bccefbc0db9e

Change-Id: Ica99759aa3f56c4b243e7199306de37c6f597bee

commit_message:
Remove pylint from the default list of tox targets

There is no such target defined, so when you execute it, it just runs
unit tests one more time. pylint calls are embedded into pep8 job, so
there is no need to have it separate in the first place.

Change-Id: I4f819cf92f32a95e9422f704f5f3e5930a7a1d1f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-vpnaas refs/changes/19/252619/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Support os-endpoint-type

Ceilometerclient will always get publicURL even though we specify
endpoint type via arguments, it is because we call kesytone session
with wrong keyword argument, which should be interface rather than
endpoint_type.

see: https://github.com/openstack/python-keystoneclient/blob/master/keystoneclient/auth/identity/base.py

Change-Id: Ic2b03bd900d913c7efd22c9b91dfaa79e0cdd4bc
Closes-Bug: #1396493
(cherry picked from commit dbf003ac6f39279cf1685d82b70d50a798d8b445)

commit_message:
Heat support for lbaasv2 Pat(1/5)

Adding new LBaaS V2 resources
1. LoadBalancer.

blueprint : lbaasv2-suport

Change-Id: Ie5d3e831285a25bd6a63a17c28fc9f7c27450173

added_lines: # # Copyright 2015 IBM Corp. # All Rights Reserved. # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import six from heat.common import exception from heat.common.i18n import _ from heat.engine import attributes from heat.engine.clients import progress from heat.engine import constraints from heat.engine import properties from heat.engine import resource from heat.engine.resources.openstack.neutron import neutron from heat.engine import support class LoadBalancer(neutron.NeutronResource): """ A resource to handle load balancer """ support_status = support.SupportStatus(version='2014.1') # Porperty inputs for the resources creation/update. PROPERTIES = ( DESCRIPTION, NAME, PROVIDER, VIP_ADDRESS, VIP_SUBNET, ADMIN_STATE_UP, ) = ( 'description', 'name', 'provider', 'vip_address', 'vip_subnet_id', 'admin_state_up', ) # Supported output attributes of the resources. ATTRIBUTES = ( ADMIN_STATE_UP_ATTR, TENANT_ID, DESCRIPTION_ATTR, NAME_ATTR, PROVIDER_ATTR, VIP_ADDRESS_ATTR, VIP_SUBNET_ATTR, ) = ( 'admin_state_up', 'tenant_id', 'description', 'name', 'provider', 'vip_address', 'vip_subnet_id', ) properties_schema = { DESCRIPTION: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Description of this loadbalancer.'), required=False, update_allowed=True ), NAME: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Name of this loadbalancer.'), required=True, update_allowed=True ), PROVIDER: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Provider for this loadbalancer.'), required=False ), VIP_ADDRESS: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('VIP address for this loadbalancer'), constraints=[ constraints.CustomConstraint('ip_addr') ], required=False, update_allowed=True ), VIP_SUBNET: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Subnet of this VIP.'), constraints=[ constraints.CustomConstraint('neutron.subnet') ], required=True ), ADMIN_STATE_UP: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.BOOLEAN, _('The administrative state of this loadbalancer.'), default=True, update_allowed=True ), } attributes_schema = { ADMIN_STATE_UP_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('The administrative state of this loadbalancer.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), TENANT_ID: attributes.Schema( _('Tenant owning this loadbalancer.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), DESCRIPTION_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('Description of this loadbalancer.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), NAME_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('Name of this loadbalancer.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), PROVIDER_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('Provider of this loadbalancdr.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), VIP_ADDRESS_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('VIP address of this loadbalancer.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), VIP_SUBNET_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('VIP subnet of this loadbalancer.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), } def handle_create(self): properties = self.prepare_properties( self.properties, self.physical_resource_name() ) loadbalancer = self.client().create_loadbalancer({'loadbalancer': properties})['loadbalancer'] self.resource_id_set(loadbalancer['id']) def _show_resource(self): return self.client().show_loadbalancer(self.resource_id)['loadbalancer'] def handle_update(self, json_snippet, tmpl_diff, prop_diff): if prop_diff: self.client().update_loadbalancer( self.resource_id, {'loadbalancer': prop_diff}) def handle_delete(self): try: self.client().delete_loadbalancer(self.resource_id) except Exception as ex: self.client_plugin().ignore_not_found(ex) else: return True class Listener(neutron.NeutronResource): """ A resource for managing Listener of the loadbalancer. """ #TODO(Bana_k) : add --connection-limit when supported. PROPERTIES = ( PROTOCOL_PORT,PROTOCOL, LOADBALANCER_ID, NAME, ADMIN_STATE_UP, DESCRIPTION, DEFAULT_TLS_CONTAINER_REF, SNI_CONTAINER_REFS, ) = ( 'protocol_port', 'protocol', 'loadbalancer_id', 'name', 'admin_state_up', 'description', 'default_tls_container_ref', 'sni_container_refs', ) ATTRIBUTES = ( PROTOCOL_PORT_ATTR,PROTOCOL_ATTR, LOADBALANCER_ID_ATTR, NAME_ATTR, ADMIN_STATE_UP_ATTR, DESCRIPTION_ATTR, DEFAULT_TLS_CONTAINER_REF_ATTR, SNI_CONTAINER_REFS_ATTR, TENANT_ID, ) = ( 'protocol_port', 'protocol', 'loadbalancer_id', 'name', 'admin_state_up', 'description', 'default_tls_container_ref', 'sni_container_refs', 'tenant_id', ) properties_schema = { PROTOCOL_PORT: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.INTEGER, _('TCP port on which to listen for client traffic '), required=True, constraints=[ constraints.Range(0, 65535), ] ), PROTOCOL: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Protocol on which to listener for the client traffic'), required=True, constraints=[ constraints.AllowedValues(['TCP', 'HTTP', 'HTTPS', 'TERMINATED_HTTPS']), ] ), LOADBALANCER_ID: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('ID of the loadbalancer with which listener' 'is associated to'), required=True, update_allowed=True ), NAME: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Name of this listener'), required=True, update_allowed=True ), ADMIN_STATE_UP: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.BOOLEAN, _('The administrative state of this listener.'), default=True, update_allowed=True ), DESCRIPTION: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Description of this listener'), update_allowed=True, required=False ), DEFAULT_TLS_CONTAINER_REF: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Default TLS container reference to retrieve TLS' 'information.'), update_allowed=True, required=False ), SNI_CONTAINER_REFS: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.LIST, _('List of TLS container references for SNI.'), update_allowed=True, required=False ), } attributes_schema = { ADMIN_STATE_UP_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('The administrative state of this listener.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), PROTOCOL_PORT_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('TCP port on which the listener listens for requests or' 'connections.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), PROTOCOL_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('Protocol of this listener to balance.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), LOADBALANCER_ID_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('Id of the loadbalancer this listener is associated to'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), NAME_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('Name of this listener'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), DESCRIPTION_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('Description of this listener'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), DEFAULT_TLS_CONTAINER_REF_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('Default TLS container reference to retrieve TLS' 'information.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), SNI_CONTAINER_REFS_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('List of TLS container references for SNI.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), TENANT_ID: attributes.Schema( _('Tenant owning this listener.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), } def handle_create(self): properties = self.prepare_properties( self.properties, self.physical_resource_name()) listener= self.client().create_listener( {'listener': properties})['listener'] self.resource_id_set(listener['id']) def _show_resource(self): return self.client().show_listener( self.resource_id)['listener'] def handle_update(self, json_snippet, tmpl_diff, prop_diff): if prop_diff: self.client().update_listener( self.resource_id, {'listener': prop_diff}) def handle_delete(self): try: self.client().delete_listener(self.resource_id) except Exception as ex: self.client_plugin().ignore_not_found(ex) else: return True class PoolMember(neutron.NeutronResource): """ A resource to handle load balancer members. """ support_status = support.SupportStatus(version='2014.1') PROPERTIES = ( POOL_ID, ADDRESS, PROTOCOL_PORT, WEIGHT, ADMIN_STATE_UP, SUBNET_ID, ) = ( 'pool_id', 'address', 'protocol_port', 'weight', 'admin_state_up', 'subnet_id' ) ATTRIBUTES = ( ADMIN_STATE_UP_ATTR, TENANT_ID, WEIGHT_ATTR, ADDRESS_ATTR, POOL_ID_ATTR, PROTOCOL_PORT_ATTR, ) = ( 'admin_state_up', 'tenant_id', 'weight', 'address', 'pool_id', 'protocol_port', ) properties_schema = { POOL_ID: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('The ID of the load balancing pool.'), required=True, update_allowed=True ), ADDRESS: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('IP address of the pool member on the pool network.'), required=True, constraints=[ constraints.CustomConstraint('ip_addr') ] ), PROTOCOL_PORT: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.INTEGER, _('TCP port on which the pool member listens for requests or ' 'connections.'), required=True, constraints=[ constraints.Range(0, 65535), ] ), WEIGHT: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.INTEGER, _('Weight of pool member in the pool (default to 1).'), constraints=[ constraints.Range(0, 256), ], update_allowed=True ), ADMIN_STATE_UP: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.BOOLEAN, _('The administrative state of the pool member.'), default=True ), SUBNET_ID: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Subnet of this member.'), constraints=[ constraints.CustomConstraint('neutron.subnet') ], required=True ), } attributes_schema = { ADMIN_STATE_UP_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('The administrative state of this pool member.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), TENANT_ID: attributes.Schema( _('Tenant owning the pool member.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), WEIGHT_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('Weight of the pool member in the pool.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), ADDRESS_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('IP address of the pool member.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), POOL_ID_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('The ID of the load balancing pool.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), PROTOCOL_PORT_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('TCP port on which the pool member listens for requests or ' 'connections.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), } def handle_create(self): pool = self.properties[self.POOL_ID] protocol_port = self.properties[self.PROTOCOL_PORT] address = self.properties[self.ADDRESS] admin_state_up = self.properties[self.ADMIN_STATE_UP] weight = self.properties[self.WEIGHT] subnet = self.properties[self.SUBNET_ID] params = { 'address': address, 'protocol_port': protocol_port, 'admin_state_up': admin_state_up, 'subnet_id': subnet } if weight is not None: params['weight'] = weight member = self.client().create_lbaas_member(pool, {'member': params})['member'] self.resource_id_set(member['id']) def _show_resource(self): pool = self.properties[self.POOL_ID] return self.client().show_lbaas_member(self.resource_id, pool)['member'] def handle_update(self, json_snippet, tmpl_diff, prop_diff): pool = self.properties[self.POOL_ID] if prop_diff: self.client().update_lbaas_member( self.resource_id, pool, {'member': prop_diff}) def handle_delete(self): pool = self.properties[self.POOL_ID] try: self.client().delete_lbaas_member(self.resource_id, pool) except Exception as ex: self.client_plugin().ignore_not_found(ex) else: return True class Pool(neutron.NeutronResource): """ A resource for managing load balancer pools in Neutron. """ PROPERTIES = ( ADMIN_STATE_UP, DESCRIPTION, SESSION_PERSISTENCE, NAME, LB_ALGORITHM, LISTENER, PROTOCOL, SESSION_PERSISTENCE_TYPE, SESSION_PERSISTENCE_COOKIE_NAME, ) = ( 'admin_state_up', 'description', 'session_persistence','name', 'lb_algorithm', 'listener_id', 'protocol', 'type', 'cookie_name' ) ATTRIBUTES = ( ADMIN_STATE_UP_ATTR, DESCRIPTION_ATTR, NAME_ATTR, LB_ALGORITHM_ATTR, LISTENER_ATTR, PROTOCOL_ATTR, TENANT_ID, ) = ( 'admin_state_up', 'description', 'name', 'lb_algorithm', 'listener_id', 'protocol', 'tenant_id' ) properties_schema = { ADMIN_STATE_UP: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.BOOLEAN, _('The administrative state of this pool.'), default=True, update_allowed=True ), DESCRIPTION: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Description of this pool.'), update_allowed=True ), SESSION_PERSISTENCE: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.MAP, _('Configuration of session persistence.'), schema={ SESSION_PERSISTENCE_TYPE: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Method of implementation of session ' 'persistence feature.'), required=True, constraints=[constraints.AllowedValues( ['SOURCE_IP', 'HTTP_COOKIE', 'APP_COOKIE'] )] ), SESSION_PERSISTENCE_COOKIE_NAME: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Name of the cookie, ' 'required if type is APP_COOKIE.') ) } ), NAME: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Name of theis pool.'), required=True, ), LB_ALGORITHM: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('The algorithm used to distribute load between the members of ' 'the pool.'), required=True, constraints=[ constraints.AllowedValues(['ROUND_ROBIN', 'LEAST_CONNECTIONS', 'SOURCE_IP']), ], update_allowed=True, ), LISTENER: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Listner ID to be associated with this pool.'), required=True, ), PROTOCOL: properties.Schema( properties.Schema.STRING, _('Protocol for balancing.'), required=True, constraints=[ constraints.AllowedValues(['TCP', 'HTTP', 'HTTPS']), ] ), } # TODO(bana_k): WIP need to change these. attributes_schema = { ADMIN_STATE_UP_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('The administrative state of this pool.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), DESCRIPTION_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('Description of the pool.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), NAME_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('Name of the pool.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), LB_ALGORITHM_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('The algorithm used to distribute load between the members ' 'of the pool.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), LISTENER_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('Listener associated with this pool'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), PROTOCOL_ATTR: attributes.Schema( _('Protocol to balance.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), TENANT_ID: attributes.Schema( _('Tenant owning the pool.'), type=attributes.Schema.STRING ), } def validate(self): res = super(Pool, self).validate() if res: return res #self._validate_depr_property_required( # self.properties, self.SUBNET, self.SUBNET_ID) #session_p = self.properties[self.VIP].get(self.VIP_SESSION_PERSISTENCE) session_p = self.properties[self.SESSION_PERSISTENCE] if session_p is None: # session persistence is not configured, skip validation return persistence_type = session_p[self.SESSION_PERSISTENCE_TYPE] if persistence_type == 'APP_COOKIE': if session_p.get(self.SESSION_PERSISTENCE_COOKIE_NAME): return msg = _('Property cookie_name is required, when ' 'session_persistence type is set to APP_COOKIE.') raise exception.StackValidationFailed(message=msg) def handle_create(self): properties = self.prepare_properties( self.properties, self.physical_resource_name()) session_p = properties[self.SESSION_PERSISTENCE] if session_p: persistence_type = session_p[self.SESSION_PERSISTENCE_TYPE] if persistence_type == 'SOURCE_IP': del properties[self.SESSION_PERSISTENCE][self.SESSION_PERSISTENCE_COOKIE_NAME] pool = self.client().create_lbaas_pool({'pool': properties})['pool'] self.resource_id_set(pool['id']) def _show_resource(self): return self.client().show_lbaas_pool(self.resource_id)['pool'] def handle_update(self, json_snippet, tmpl_diff, prop_diff): if prop_diff: self.client().update_lbaas_pool(self.resource_id, {'pool': prop_diff}) def handle_delete(self): try: self.client().delete_lbaas_pool(self.resource_id) except Exception as ex: self.client_plugin().ignore_not_found(ex) else: return True def resource_mapping(): return { 'OS::Lbaas::PoolMember': PoolMember, 'OS::Lbaas::LoadBalancer': LoadBalancer, 'OS::Lbaas::Listener': Listener, 'OS::Lbaas::Pool': Pool, }

commit_message:
Refactor Home controller

This makes use of previously created services so that we can remove this
logic from the controller, delegating it to the specialized services,
keeping the controller thin.

Change-Id: Idc7aba6e046b007c6605d056ccbd17f07183d139
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-health refs/changes/32/245832/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: function HomeController(healthService, startDate, projectService) { var byFailRateDesc = function(project1, project2) { return project2.metrics.failRate - project1.metrics.failRate; var processData = function(data) { var projects = projectService.createProjects(data.runs); var dateStats = projectService.getStatsByDate(projects); var entries = getChartEntries(dateStats); vm.chartData = [ { key: 'Passes', values: entries.passes, color: "blue" }, { key: 'Failures', values: entries.failures, color: "red" } ]; vm.chartDataRate = [{ key: '% Failures', values: entries.failRate }]; vm.projects = projects .sort(byFailRateDesc) .map(function(project) { return generateGaugeData(project); }); }; var getChartEntries = function(dateStats) { var entries = { passes: [], failures: [], failRate: [] }; angular.forEach(dateStats, function(stats) { entries.passes.push(generateChartData(stats.date, stats.metrics.passes)); entries.failures.push(generateChartData(stats.date, stats.metrics.failures)); entries.failRate.push(generateChartData(stats.date, stats.metrics.failRate)); }); return entries; }; var generateChartData = function(date, value) { return { x: date.getTime(), y: value }; }; var generateGaugeData = function(project) { return { name: project.name, data: [ { key: 'Passes', value: project.metrics.passes, color: 'blue' }, { key: 'Failures', value: project.metrics.failures, color: 'red' } ] }; var loadData = function() { }; // ViewModel var vm = this; vm.processData = processData; vm.loadData = loadData;

var failures = project.data[1].value; var totalTests = passes + failures; var percentOfFailures = failures / totalTests * 100; return percentOfFailures; }; var byPercentageOfFailuresDesc = function(project1, project2) { var percentage1 = percentageOfFailures(project1); var percentage2 = percentageOfFailures(project2); return percentage2 - percentage1; function processData(data) { vm.chartData = []; vm.chartDataRate = []; vm.projects = []; var projects = {}; var passEntries = []; var failEntries = []; var failRateEntries = []; var sumProjectMetrics = function(project) { var sumProject = projects[projectName]; if (typeof sumProject === "undefined") { // create initial data containers for each gauge chart on-the-fly sumProject = { name: projectName, data: [ { key: 'Passes', value: 0, color: 'blue' }, { key: 'Failures', value: 0, color: 'red' } ] }; projects[projectName] = sumProject; } if (project.fail > 0) { totalFail += 1; sumProject.data[1].value += 1; } else if (project.pass > 0) { totalPass += 1; sumProject.data[0].value += 1; } for (var dateString in data.runs) { if (data.runs.hasOwnProperty(dateString)) { var date = dateString; var totalPass = 0; var totalFail = 0; var failRate = 0; var DEFAULT_FAIL_RATE = 0; var reqProjects = data.runs[date]; var projectName = ''; for (projectName in reqProjects) { if (reqProjects.hasOwnProperty(projectName)) { reqProjects[projectName].forEach(sumProjectMetrics); } } failRate = totalFail / (totalFail + totalPass) || DEFAULT_FAIL_RATE; // parse dates and create data series' for the main chart var time = new Date(date).getTime(); passEntries.push({ x: time, y: totalPass }); failEntries.push({ x: time, y: totalFail }); failRateEntries.push({ x: new Date(date).getTime(), y: failRate }); } } vm.chartData.push({ key: 'Passes', values: passEntries, color: "blue" }); vm.chartData.push({ key: 'Failures', values: failEntries, color: "red" }); vm.chartDataRate.push({ key: '% Failures', values: failRateEntries }); vm.projects = Object.keys(projects) .map(function(name) { return projects[name]; }) .sort(byPercentageOfFailuresDesc); } function loadData() { }

commit_message:
Enable coverage reporting.

This patch enables code coverage reporting during unit tests via
the `karma-coverage` plugin, and writes them in HTML form to the
`cover` directory where they can be collected as part of the test
job output.

Change-Id: Ic280664eaf5d5f85acfaeb3f54b314129e9ed786
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-health refs/changes/61/245361/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: reporters: ['spec', 'coverage'], coverageReporter: { type: 'html', dir: 'cover', instrumenterOptions: { istanbul: {noCompact: true} } },

This service is responsible for performing operations on multiple

commit_message:
Add Project Service

This service is responsible for performing operations on multiple
projects at a time, so that we can remove this logic from our
controllers, making it easier to understand and test.

Change-Id: If3d0bde9b05bf44fbab7ff73b04c9028e1f298f0

commit_message:
Add factory to create Project models

This is the first step toward removing the business logic that currently
lives in the controllers, making them responsible for too much, into
specific objects that know how to perform them.

This allows us to have better tests and will also allow our controller
to be a lot thinner in the following commits (also allowing for
better/easier tests).

Co-Authored-By: Caio Carrara <ccarrara@thoughtworks.com>
Change-Id: I5499876b9fbbfcd616a2f5d823c416f4fee3ddbe

added_lines: 'use strict'; var angular = require('angular'); var factoriesModule = require('./_index.js'); /** * @ngInject */ var ProjectFactory = function() { var factory = {}; factory.create = function(name) { var project = {}; project.name = name; project.runs = []; project.totalPasses = 0; project.totalFailures = 0; project.totalSkips = 0; var aggregateRuns = function(runEntries) { var aggregatedMetrics = { passes: 0, failures: 0, skips: 0 }; runEntries.forEach(function(run) { if (run.fail > 0) { aggregatedMetrics.failures += 1; } else if (run.pass > 0) { aggregatedMetrics.passes += 1; } else { aggregatedMetrics.skips += 1; } }); return aggregatedMetrics; }; var updateTotalMetrics = function(aggregatedMetrics) { project.totalPasses += aggregatedMetrics.passes; project.totalFailures += aggregatedMetrics.failures; project.totalSkips += aggregatedMetrics.skips; }; project.addRuns = function(date, runEntries) { if (!runEntries || runEntries.length === 0) { return; } var run = { date: new Date(date), entries: runEntries }; var aggregatedMetrics = aggregateRuns(runEntries); angular.extend(run, aggregatedMetrics); project.runs.push(run); updateTotalMetrics(aggregatedMetrics); }; return project; }; return factory; }; factoriesModule.factory('ProjectFactory', ProjectFactory);

commit_message:
[Docker] Docker applications developer reference

Change-Id: I90e9f5ab67829fd4c9dd6256ed835a458da692eb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-apps refs/changes/69/251769/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Docker Interface Library ======================== This library provides 3 major things: * DockerApplication: base class that all Docker applications must inherit. Provides a way to define image name and docker container parameters. * DockerContainerHost: interface for applications that provide Docker application hosting capabilities. Docker applications use this interface to deploy themselves on the Docker host. * Data structures that are pass between DockerApplications and DockerContainerHosts. They define things like volumes, ports etc. Most important data structure is DockerContainer which describes the container itself. DockerApplication ================= This is the base class for all Docker applications. At minimum all inheritors must provide an implementation of `getContainer` method. Everything else is either optional or implemented in the base class. It has the following properties: * `host`: an instance of `DockerContainerHost`. This is the hosting provider (`DockerStandaloneHost`, `KubernetesPod`, etc.) that applications should be deployed to. * `applicationEndpoints`: output property that is filled with application endpoints after deployment. See below for exact format details. Class also has the following methods: * `getContainer`: returns an instance of `DockerContainer` class that describes container information. Alternatively method can return a properties dictionary that would automatically be converted to `DockerContainer` by MuranoPL. This method must be implemented by inheritors! * `deploy`: used to deploy Docker application on given `DockerContainerHost`. This method is already implemented in this class and should not be overridden by inheritors. It relies on the information returned by `getContainer`. * `getConnectionTo`: used to get full endpoint for another Docker application's port when there is a need to connect two Docker applications. Requires three parameters: * `application`: an instance of `DockerApplication` that we want to talk to. * `port`: port number of the target application. * `protocol`: `TCP` or `UDP`. Returns a dictionary with two keys - `host` and `port` that represent the endpoint. Note that target application must be deployed before calling this method so it is advised to call `deploy()` first. See `DockerGrafana/DockerInfluxDB` as an example or connected Docker applications. * `onInstallationStart`: a method that get get called when installation starts. May be overridden by inheritor class to provide extra logging or reporting. * `onInstallationFinish`: a method that get get called when installation ends. May be overridden by inheritor class to provide extra logging or reporting. DockerContainer =============== This is a data structure defining a Docker container. It has the following properties: * `name`: container name. Must be unique within single `DockerContainerHost`. This is the same as application name for regular applications. * `image`: Docker image name. * `commands`: optional list of shell commands to execute upon container start. * `env`: a dictionary of environment key-values (inputs for Docker containers) * `ports`: a list of `ApplicationPort` instances. This is a list of ports that need to be opened/exposed by the container. * `volumes`: an optional mapping that defines volumes that need to be mounted into Docker container. Keys are the paths within container and values are instances of DockerVolume. ApplicationPort =============== Defines a network port that need to be exposed by the application. This is a structure with three properties: * `port`: port number * `protocol`: `TCP` or `UDP` * `scope`: one of `public`, `cloud`, `host` or `internal`. This property specifies the scope of port visibility: within the single docker instance (on single server) - `host`, within single `DockerContainerHost` - `internal`, single OpenStack cloud - `cloud` or `public` for ports that are bind to public floating IP. DockerVolume ============ Represents base class for Docker volumes. One of the two inheritors must be used: * `DockerTempVolume`: temporary storage space * `DockerHostVolume`: a directory on the host machine that is mounted inside container. The path on host server is specified by the `path` property of `DockerHostVolume`. DockerContainerHost =================== Defines an interface that all applications capable of hosting Docker applications must implement. Currently there are two implementations of this interface: `DockerStandaloneHost` and `KubernetesPod`. It has the following property: * `name`: name of the application instance. It also has the following methods: * `hostContainer`: Docker applications call this method to register Docker containers on the Docker host during deployment. It accepts single argument - `container` - an instance of DockerContainer class. `deleteContainer`: deletes container from Docker host. Container is identified by its name through `name` parameter. `getEndpoints`: returns a list of endpoints for specified Docker container Container is identified by its name through `applicationName` parameter. `getInternalScopeId`: returns an common identifier for all Docker hosts belonging to the same container manager (host aggregation used to group together endpoints of `internal` scope.

commit_message:
Send extra_kernel_options on pxe_append_params

When we started using ironic pxe template, we lost the ability
to send extra_kernel_options. According to our conversations, this
should be sent on pxe_append_params.
As this element was already being used for screen, I decided to make
this step a bit more generalist, and also send the extra_kernel_options
on same task.

Change-Id: I6c4a5eeb64185cc91c29b169349fff426cc53334
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/bifrost refs/changes/55/252955/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: "For agent, send extra params" line="pxe_append_params=systemd.journald.forward_to_console=yes {{extra_kernel_options | default('')}}"

commit_message:
(WIP) Test pupept-openstack modules on more Puppet

  This commit adds the jobs needed to test the old style of packaging
  opensource Puppet and the new PC1[1] style.

  Without this our modules are stuck at validating beaker tests on
  3.8.x.

  [1] http://docs.puppetlabs.com/puppet/4.3/reference/whered_it_go.html

Change-Id: Idfd92acab9c6bd74cfdb3352adbd431dce6507ae

commit_message:
Add openstack-powervm to accessbot/gerritbot

Add the openstack-powervm channel to accessbot and enable gerritbot
reporting for the nova-powervm, networking-powervm, and
ceilometer-powervm projects in openstack-powervm

Change-Id: Idae4d4bce5a4f176c275126c1e284d76d3865a09

commit_message:
Support "server list" searching by both image name and ID.

Nova API only supports list servers searching by image ID.
In OSC, we can support both image name and ID by mapping
the name to ID.

This patch also fix the inconsistent doc in .py and .rst files.

Closes-Bug: 1521492

Change-Id: I70613843f82d74732bd32a457cd4a31aba57825f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/58/251658/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: help=_('Search by image (name or ID)'), # Nova only supports list servers searching by image ID. So if a # image name is given, map it to ID. image_id = None if parsed_args.image: image_id = utils.find_resource(compute_client.images, parsed_args.image).id 'image': image_id,

commit_message:
Add multi deletion testcase for openstack volume delete

Change-Id: Id8e6e8311e46e4c8644d41d773aeb27416ca6a7e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient refs/changes/97/250897/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from mock import call def setup_volumes_mock(self, count): volumes = volume_fakes.FakeVolume.create_volumes(count=count) self.volumes_mock.get = volume_fakes.FakeVolume.get_volumes( volumes, 0) return volumes def test_volume_delete_one_volume(self): volumes = self.setup_volumes_mock(count=1) volumes[0].id ("volumes", [volumes[0].id]) self.volumes_mock.delete.assert_called_with(volumes[0].id) def test_volume_delete_multi_volumes(self): volumes = self.setup_volumes_mock(count=3) arglist = [] verifylist = [] for v in volumes: arglist.append(v.id) verifylist = [ ('volumes', arglist), ] parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, verifylist) self.cmd.take_action(parsed_args) calls = [] for v in volumes: calls.append(call(v.id)) self.volumes_mock.delete.assert_has_calls(calls)
deleted_lines: self.volumes_mock.get.return_value = fakes.FakeResource( None, copy.deepcopy(volume_fakes.VOLUME), loaded=True) def test_volume_delete(self): volume_fakes.volume_id ("volumes", [volume_fakes.volume_id]) self.volumes_mock.delete.assert_called_with(volume_fakes.volume_id)

commit_message:
Allow customization of db sync command line

Add parameter to nova::db::sync class to allow end
users to add command line parameters to the db sync command.

Change-Id: I89dea475495d5903d953ff4492ad2e0f12a293c1
Partial-bug: #1472740
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/09/241009/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :command => '/usr/bin/nova-manage db sync', describe "overriding extra_params" do let :params do { :extra_params => '--config-file /etc/nova/nova.conf', } end it { is_expected.to contain_exec('nova-db-sync').with( :command => '/usr/bin/nova-manage --config-file /etc/nova/nova.conf db sync', :refreshonly => 'true', :logoutput => 'on_failure' ) end

Fix an issue where when local conductor is used, the DB driver for
servicegroup will not handle transient DB problems gracefully.  The

commit_message:
Handle DB failures in servicegroup DB driver

Fix an issue where when local conductor is used, the DB driver for
servicegroup will not handle transient DB problems gracefully.  The
patch makes the behavior consistent with messaging timeouts if remote
conductor is used.

Change-Id: Ie736e7b64ea4f60f78878c8713ce826702f9f05e
Closes-Bug: 1505471
(cherry picked from commit 5252bba03e43c71f90cb2a657e6a7f396d04be75)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/91/247491/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_db import exception as db_exception import oslo_messaging as messaging @mock.patch.object(objects.Service, 'save') def _test_report_state_error(self, exc_cls, upd_mock): upd_mock.side_effect = exc_cls("service save failed") service_ref = objects.Service(host='fake-host', topic='compute', report_count=10) service = mock.MagicMock(model_disconnected=False, service_ref=service_ref) fn = self.servicegroup_api._driver._report_state fn(service) # fail if exception not caught def test_report_state_remote_error_handling(self): # test error handling using remote conductor self.flags(use_local=False, group='conductor') self._test_report_state_error(messaging.MessagingTimeout) def test_report_state_local_error_handling(self): # if using local conductor, the db driver must handle DB errors self.flags(use_local=True, group='conductor') # mock an oslo.db DBError as it's an exception base class for # oslo.db DB errors (eg DBConnectionError) self._test_report_state_error(db_exception.DBError)

commit_message:
Add Python-cli and init run dir to PG elements

[ALL] Install the native Postgresql Python client (psycopg2).
[FEDORA] Add an entry to initialize the Postgres runtime directory
at boot time.

Partial-Bug: bug/1514569
Change-Id: I9d6b3df5bebc3c499cea8306f5a1a6bab18adef6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-integration refs/changes/36/247836/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Create a volatile directory for runtime files. echo "d /var/run/postgresql/ 0755 postgres postgres" > /lib/tmpfiles.d/postgresql.conf # Install the native Python client. dnf install -y postgresql-devel python-devel pip install psycopg2

commit_message:
Remove version from setup.cfg

Per [1] we now use the git repository for knowing the version instead
of modifying the setup.cfg file.

[1]
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-November/080692.html

commit_message:
Allow customization of db sync command line

Add parameter to heat::db::sync to allow end
users to add command line parameters to the db sync command.

Change-Id: Id9de1022481fbeedc3db78a3dd2e3c5f2a962e10
Partial-bug: #1472740

commit_message:
Disable clean_nodes by default

This patch sets the conductor/clean_nodes configuration option
for Ironic to False by default. To maintain the same behavior
of the old ramdisk.

The tripleoclient `openstack baremetal introspection bulk`
command needs to be fixed to account for the time it takes
to move from manageable to available in order to have cleaning
turned on by default.

Change-Id: I23c3e7ada3da8085957e86406527e9e5202bdd69
Closes-Bug: 1517449
(cherry picked from commit 246d1e8595945f74095b3ec70c63f493f615eed6)

added_lines: ironic::conductor::clean_nodes: false

'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-11-01 17:54:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/97db99fa5858ccd3e38c661a37d4c9279767517e', 'message': "fix DVR floating IP shortcut issue

Two things will cause DVR floating IP 'shortcut'
issue mentioned in bug #1462154:
1) DVR floating IP DNAT iptable rules will do
   DNAT to packets for VMs when they pinging
   floating IPs, which belong to VMs on the
   same router's private subnets, on the same
   host.
2) Current designment will add floating IPs onto
   rfp devices, so even we fix 1), packets will
   go to rfp devices, the wrong destinations.

This patch will try to fix the issue by:
1) fix PREROUTING rule for DVR floating IPs.
2) remove code try to add floating IPs onto rfp
   devices. And for method like 'scan_fip_ports',
   try scanning floating IP routes in fip netns
   instead.

Closes-bug: #1462154
Change-Id: Ief01769337729bd37ef7d1e9ed79b035bcc2dfa0
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2015-11-02 06:40:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/2ad32b382186938f6e5bc3c5a8c2692e9212f3a1', 'message': "fix DVR floating IP shortcut issue

   same router's private subnets, on the same
   host.
2) Current designment will add floating IPs onto
   rfp devices, so even we fix 1), packets will

This patch will try to fix the issue by:
1) fix PREROUTING rule for DVR floating IPs.
2) remove code try to add floating IPs onto rfp
   devices. And for method like 'scan_fip_ports',

Closes-bug: #1462154
Change-Id: Ief01769337729bd37ef7d1e9ed79b035bcc2dfa0
"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2015-11-02 08:43:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/56e6faf80c2afa389febaa10d5cd7e56d839152d', 'message': "fix DVR floating IP shortcut issue

Two things will cause DVR floating IP 'shortcut'
issue mentioned in bug #1462154:
1) DVR floating IP DNAT iptable rules will do
   DNAT to packets for VMs when they pinging
   floating IPs, which belong to VMs on the
   same router's private subnets, on the same
   host.
2) Current designment will add floating IPs onto
   rfp devices, so even we fix 1), packets will
   go to rfp devices, the wrong destinations.

This patch will try to fix the issue by:
1) fix PREROUTING rule for DVR floating IPs.
2) remove code try to add floating IPs onto rfp
   devices. And for method like 'scan_fip_ports',
   try scanning floating IP routes in fip netns
   instead.

Closes-bug: #1462154
Change-Id: Ief01769337729bd37ef7d1e9ed79b035bcc2dfa0
"}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2015-11-02 14:48:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/52281edb9f8790d58fdbea2d6563beb5f1b04c58', 'message': 'fix DVR floating IP shortcut issue

Currently, there is a "shortcut" issue existing on DVR floating IP.
Image we have VM-1 and VM-2 on the same host, and their subnets are
attached onto the same router, and VM-2 has floating IP associated.
When VM-1 ping VM-2 by floating IP, its packets will directly routed
by DVR local router to VM-2, not going external network by passing
DVR edge router.
DVR floating IP DNAT iptable rules in PREROUTING chain make that
happened. Those DNAT rules will change packet destination address IP
without making judgment on it's a ingress or egress traffic.
Fixing PREROUTING rules for DVR floating IP will be one point this
patch trying to do.
After we fix DNAT rules, rfp device in DVR local router namespace,
which hosting floating IP address will "hijack" VM-1's packets to VM-2
floating IP. So this patch will also try to remove code which try
to add floating IP onto rfp device, and change methods like
"scan_fip_ports" to try scanning for floating IP routes in fip netns
instead.

Closes-bug: #1462154
Change-Id: Ief01769337729bd37ef7d1e9ed79b035bcc2dfa0
'}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2015-11-02 15:11:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/48d9331d81b93dcf8a815cd62099cee5dea68416', 'message': 'fix DVR floating IP shortcut issue

Currently, there is a "shortcut" issue existing on DVR floating IP.
Imagine we have VM-1 and VM-2 on the same host, and their subnets are
attached onto the same router, and VM-2 has floating IP associated.
When VM-1 ping VM-2 by floating IP, its packets will directly routed
by DVR local router to VM-2, not going external network by passing
DVR edge router.
DVR floating IP DNAT iptable rules in PREROUTING chain make that
happened. Those DNAT rules will change packet destination address IP
without making judgment on it's a ingress or egress traffic.
Fixing PREROUTING rules for DVR floating IP will be one point this
patch trying to do.
After we fix DNAT rules, rfp device in DVR local router namespace,
which hosting floating IP address will get VM-1's packets to VM-2
floating IP, and stop the egree traffic going to DVR edge router.
So this patch will also try to remove code which try to add floating
IP onto rfp device, and change methods like "scan_fip_ports" to try
scanning for floating IP routes in fip netns instead.

Closes-bug: #1462154
Change-Id: Ief01769337729bd37ef7d1e9ed79b035bcc2dfa0
'}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2015-11-03 10:41:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/442e601214991c49fb56ec1d096dc9951bead74d', 'message': 'fix DVR floating IP iptables rules

Currently it is possible for local VM traffic being forwarded directly to
the local floating IP instead of being routed via DVR edge router.

If two VMs on the same host are attached to the same local DVR router,
and at least one of the VMs has a floating IP associated with it,
then traffic between local VMs via the floating IP are passed directly
instead of being routed externally via the DVR edge router.

This is caused by DVR floating IP DNAT rules in the iptables PREROUTING chain.
The DNAT rules do not check if the traffic is ingress or egress before
changing the destination IP address of the packet. This patch will try
to fix that.

The patch also removes code which tries to add the floating IP to the rfp

edge router.

floating IP routes in the fip netns instead.

commit_message:
WIP fix DVR floating IP iptables rules

WIP: will update UT and commit message later

Currently it is possible for local VM traffic being forwarded directly to
the local floating IP instead of being routed via DVR edge router.

If two VMs on the same host are attached to the same local DVR router,
and at least one of the VMs has a floating IP associated with it,
then traffic between local VMs via the floating IP are passed directly
instead of being routed externally via the DVR edge router.

This is caused by DVR floating IP DNAT rules in the iptables PREROUTING chain.
The DNAT rules do not check if the traffic is ingress or egress before
changing the destination IP address of the packet. This patch will try
to fix that.

The patch also removes code which tries to add the floating IP to the rfp
device in the DVR local router namespace. Since DVR floating IP DNAT rules
no longer change destination IP address for egress traffic, the rfp device
hosting floating IP address will prevents egress traffic from reaching the
edge router.
Since rfp device in DVR local router namespace no longer hosts floating IPs,
we should modify methods such as "scan_fip_ports" to try scanning for
floating IP routes in the fip netns instead.

Closes-bug: #1462154
Change-Id: Ief01769337729bd37ef7d1e9ed79b035bcc2dfa0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/77/240677/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: return [('PREROUTING', '-d %s -j DNAT --to %s' % existing_cidrs = self.get_router_cidrs(device) fips_to_remove = ( ip_cidr for ip_cidr in existing_cidrs - new_cidrs if common_utils.is_cidr_host(ip_cidr))

commit_message:
Add new alarm for the galera checks

This commit adds a new alarm to alert on the current mysql connection
count, based on percentage thresholds of configured maximum (80 warn,
90 critical)

Original github issue:
https://github.com/rcbops/rpc-openstack/issues/550

Depends on the following merging (this is the commit to add the new
metrics to the plugin):
https://github.com/rcbops/rpc-maas/pull/226

Change-Id: Iacd7a809b11fe3ca09deba8ee09fafbe08a13b03
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/90/251890/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - { 'name': 'percentage_used_mysql_connections', 'criteria': ':set consecutiveCount={{ maas_alarm_local_consecutive_count }} if (percentage(metric["mysql_current_connections"], metric["mysql_max_configured_connections"]) > {{ mysql_connection_critical_threshold }} ) { return new AlarmStatus(CRITICAL, "Mysql connections has exceeded {{ mysql_connection_critical_threshold }}% of configured maximum"); } if (percentage(metric["mysql_current_connections"], metric["mysql_max_configured_connections"]) > {{ mysql_connection_warning_threshold }} ) { return new AlarmStatus(WARNING, "Mysql connections has exceeded {{ mysql_connection_warning_threshold }}% of configured maximum"); }' }

commit_message:
devstack: Fix dib image location

We're building astara.qcow2 but pointing glance to akanda.qcow2.

This fixes it and should fix the dsvm-src jobs.

Change-Id: I2e87e8bdcc3ad17d8689cd74e9697dc371849006

commit_message:
[Sahara] Get urls of datasources safer

There are possible problems with retrieving datasources urls,
we can avoid that if we will wrap retrieving with try/except block.

Closes-bug: 1502854
Change-Id: I17599a8559dc0a7e33d1f70033000a01d5396dc6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/76/237976/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: object_names['input_url'] = job_execution.data_source_urls.get( job_execution.input_id) object_names['output_url'] = job_execution.data_source_urls.get( job_execution.output_id)

commit_message:
Put py34 first in the env order of tox

To solve the problem of "db type could not be determined" on py34 we
have to run first the py34 env to, then, run py27. This patch puts py34
first on the tox.ini list of envs to avoid this problem to happen.

Change-Id: I18c626fb7dc8cc805117598946426e54fefed829
Closes-Bug: #1489059
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/aodh refs/changes/36/252436/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: envlist = py34,py27,pep8

commit_message:
Remove db access in VNX driver

DB access should be removed in all CG related
operations. This patch is removing the DB access
in VNX driver.

Change-Id: Ifee0cdcaba41d39500c1ce7aef0d15b2737e6a20
Closes-Bug: 1511663

commit_message:
Simplify LimitTests

Limit tests currently used for SQL backend testing are too complex.
Due to this complexity they could be used for SQL only. They assumed
possibility to create a domain, while it is not possible when LDAP
identity backend is used with multidomain support.

Simplify LimitTests and assume that a default domain is used for all
operations.

Change-Id: I77d581e03dae86c299ce2e1e56164dde3c4ad72a

commit_message:
db: Database Query Profiling

This spec proposes to introduce a way to measure db query execution
times using sqlalchemy events. This profiling information can be
very useful for tuning database performance.

Change-Id: I283877017e7f13c22eafae63ca5fd7456fa7a1ae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/89/247589/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ======================== Database Query Profiling ======================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo.db/+spec/database-query-profiling Slowdowns in querying database can have disproportionately large adverse effects on the various services of Openstack. Thus it is extremely important to the OpenStack projects that the database be well-tuned. This in turn requires database profiling in order to determine the best places to focus for tuning. Problem description =================== Currently, database tuning is probably carried out in a more ad-hoc fashion across different OpenStack deployments. While performance characteristics may vary with respect to cloud size and usage patterns, all deployments could benefit from having database profiling information available. Use Cases --------- As a developer/operator, I want my Openstack databases to be well-tuned and not be a bottleneck for end-user API responses or for the other services. Proposed change =============== Tap into sqlalchemy's core events such as 'before_cursor_execute' and 'after_cursor_execute' to measure the query execution times. Register listener functions for events 'before_cursor_execute' and 'after_cursor_execute' .. code-block:: python sqlalchemy.event.listen(engine, 'before_cursor_execute', _before_cursor_execute) sqlalchemy.event.listen(engine, 'after_cursor_execute', _after_cursor_execute) In the listener function for 'before_cursor_execute' event, add the query start time to connection info. .. code-block:: python def _before_cursor_execute(conn, cursor, statement, parameters, context, executemany): ... conn.info['query_start_time'] = timeutils.utcnow() ... Then, in the listener function for 'after_cursor_execute' event, fetch the query start time from connection info, calculate the time elapsed and log it. .. code-block:: python def _after_cursor_execute(conn, cursor, statement, parameters, context, executemany): ... start_time = conn.info.get('query_start_time') total = timeutil.delta_seconds(start_time, timeutils.utcnow()) LOG.debug("Query time: %f" % total) ... The above profiling can be turned on/off using a newly introduced config option, profile_queries. Alternatives ------------ - We could enable debug logging in sqlalchemy engine using the oslo.db config 'connection_debug'. Once enabled, sqlalchemy logs the query and corresponding result set after all query executions. We could use the timestamps in the logs to measure the query execution times to a certain extent based on the previous log message. Although this may work in principle, it may not be accurate. And, it isn't a direct measurement of query execution times. - We could do nothing and allow the current method of ad-hoc profiling and tuning. Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- None Security impact --------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ As this change is tapping into sqlalchemy's events, it is unlikely that there'd be a significant performance penalty. However, since we have listeners executing before and after the query execution, there would be a minor performance penalty but it is quite likely small enough to be ignored. Exact numbers on performance penalty, if any, can be studied in further detail as we progress with this change. Other deployer impact --------------------- The new config option, profile_queries, will be introduced and turned off by default. There would be no impact out of the box. A deployer may have to enable debug logging or other appropriate config in services that use oslo.db to report query execution times. Developer impact ---------------- Developers of Openstack projects that use oslo.db would have to use the new config option, profile_queries, to enable/disable query profiling. Testing Impact -------------- Unit and functional tests should suffice for testing this change. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: hemanth-makkapati Other contributors: None Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: Mitaka Work Items ---------- Write and register listener functions for 'before_cursor_execute' and 'after_cursor_execute' events Incubation ========== N/A Adoption -------- N/A Library ------- N/A Anticipated API Stabilization ----------------------------- N/A Documentation Impact ==================== Information about the profiling option should appear in the Operations Guide. Dependencies ============ None References ========== None .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
Put py34 first in the env order of tox

To solve the problem of "db type could not be determined" on py34 we
have to run first the py34 env to, then, run py27. This patch puts py34
first on the tox.ini list of envs to avoid this problem to happen.

Change-Id: Id54bb80944385579cfa136fce78cb5be55393f81
Closes-Bug: #1489059
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/39/252439/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: envlist = py34,py27,pep8

commit_message:
Allow optionally retaining weakref(s) to listener callbacks

Instead of always having a strong reference to listener
callbacks (which can cause the garbage collector to retain
those objects unnecessarily) allow for optionally registering
the callbacks as weak (defaults to false) so that the garbage
collector can delete it as needed and earlier.

Depends-On: I3ac7ba5eaa1de3cee5739287703dd0b3565a7484

Change-Id: I3d8b1f607152cb0f5768ce6380692dca25aa50e1

commit_message:
Fixing incorrect work of the _initialize_testr method

When we execute `rally verify start system-wide-install`, we get
"OSError: [Errno 13] Permission denied" error. So this patch is
intended to fix the issue.

Change-Id: Icb684c96c2c74fbb3ac2815387d0ea790ff3a3c5

commit_message:
Minor fixes to TLS related resources

* Fixed a comment to avoid ambiguity with concepts in Heat
* Removed default values from necessary parameters in the TLS
  environment
* Simplified setting of the cert/key into a file.

Change-Id: I351778150a6fbf7affe1a0fddb1abb9869324dfc

Remove version from setup.cfg

Per [1] we now want to use the git repository for knowing the version
instead of just trying to modify the setup.cfg file.

[1]

commit_message:
Only deploy .my.cnf file on galera/utility containers

The original bug was opened because .my.cnf (with sensitive root credentials)
was being deployed on compute hosts without needing to be there. This patch
restricts the deployment of .my.cnf files to the galera/utility containers
only. This improves security while still allowing deployers to diagnose galera
server issues on the galera server containers themselves, and to access the
database from the utility containers for diagnostic purposes.

Closes-bug: 1510596
Implements: blueprint limit-mysql-config-distribution
Change-Id: I42f39cbfcb02b97846894592d642ac0c58a82b02

commit_message:
Use flat_networks=* default for the ml2 plugin

We are setting our flat_networks setting for the ml2 plugin
manually to '' which as of neutron git commit
cb712c5a9ee2717f5d34b00a420529b842db90c7 causes a
'Flat networks are disabled' error to occur when
we attempt to create the ctlplane network.

This patch drops the configurion of flat_networks from
instack and instead relies on the puppet-neutron default
of '*' which will work.

Change-Id: I880c9a159a46d9a288cb1f8bf79af30e5045d5ab
Closes-bug: #1515315
(cherry picked from commit f9ed51c5da8d0d82a9c83e82df862f3bdd083cba)
